'''(Charles) Bruce Greyson''' (born October 1946) is Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry and Neurobehavioral Sciences at the [[University of Virginia]]. He is co-author of ''[[Irreducible Mind]]'' (2007) and co-editor of ''The Handbook of Near-Death Experiences'' (2009). Greyson has written many journal articles, and has given media interviews, on the subject of [[near death experience]]s.
==Academic appointments== Greyson is Chester F. Carlson Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry and Neurobehavioral Sciences, and the former director of The Division of Perceptual Studies (DOPS),<ref>[http://www.healthsystem.virginia.edu/internet/personalitystudies/ Division of Perceptual Studies, University of Virginia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061006075133/http://www.healthsystem.virginia.edu/internet/personalitystudies/ |date=2006-10-06 }}</ref> formerly the Division of Personality Studies, at the [[University of Virginia]]. He is also a Professor of Psychiatric Medicine in the Department of Psychiatric Medicine, Division of Outpatient Psychiatry, at the University of Virginia.
==Research work== Greyson is a [[researcher]] in the field of [[near-death studies]] and has been called the father of research in near-death experiences.<ref>{{cite web |title=The Brain and Belief|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/kuar/.artsmain/article/11/1172/1115568/Radio/The.Brain.and.Belief/ |publisher=[[Public Radio International]] |year=2010 |quote=Bruce Greyson is considered the father of research into the Near Death Experience. |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Edwardsville Woman has Near-death Experience |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=ND&s_site=belleville&p_multi=ND&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F8B91CC5593B9CE&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |journal=Belleville News-Democrat |date=January 21, 2003 |quote=[Greyson] called 'the father of near-death experience research' by some... |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref> Greyson, along with [[Kenneth Ring]], Michael Sabom, and others, built on the research of [[Raymond Moody]], Russell Noyes Jr and [[Elisabeth Kübler-Ross]]. Greyson's scale to measure the aspects of near-death experiences<ref>Greyson, Bruce (1983). The near-death experience scale: Construction, reliability, and validity. ''Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease'', Jun;171(6):369-75.</ref> has been widely used, being cited 95 times as of early 2010.<ref>Google Scholar, [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&lr=&cites=2160880025097478512&um=1&ie=UTF-8&ei=NE2ES-P9Eoz8lAeGwbHVAQ&sa=X&oi=science_links&resnum=1&ct=sl-citedby&ved=0CA0QzgIwAA Citations of Greyson (1983)]. Accessed February 23, 2010.</ref> He also devised a 19-item scale to assess experience of [[Kundalini energy|kundalini]], the Physio-Kundalini Scale.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Bruce Greyson |year=1993 |title=Near-death experiences and the physio-kundalini syndrome |journal=Journal of Religion and Health |volume=32 |pages=277–290 |issue=4 |doi=10.1007/BF00990954 |pmid=24271550}}</ref>
Greyson wrote the overview of Near Death Experiences for the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' and was the Editor-in-Chief of the ''[[Journal of Near-Death Studies]]'' (formerly ''Anabiosis'') from 1982 through 2007. Greyson has been interviewed or consulted many times in the press on the subject of near-death experiences.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Near-death experience is debated |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2SQdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S6UEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6536,5501658&dq=bruce-greyson+near-death+research&hl=en |journal=[[The Tuscaloosa News]] citing story in [[Los Angeles Times]] |date=May 23, 1982 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Jane E. Brody |title=HEALTH; Personal Health |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/11/17/us/health-personal-health.html?pagewanted=all |journal=[[The New York Times]] |date=November 17, 1988 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Anne Longley |title=A Glimpse Beyond: A Psychiatrist Plumbs the Near-Death Experience |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20103567,00.html |journal=[[People (magazine)|People]] |volume=42 |date=August 1, 1994 |accessdate=February 23, 2010 |issue=5}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Douglas Fox |title=Light at the end of the tunnel |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg19225731.300-light-at-the-end-of-the-tunnel.html?page=3 |journal=[[New Scientist]] |volume=2573 |date=October 17, 2006 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Benedict Carey |title=The Afterlife of Near-Death |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/18/weekinreview/18carey.html |journal=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 17, 2009 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | author=Daniel Williams |title=At the Hour Of Our Death |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1657919,00.html |journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 31, 2007 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Science Notebook |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/49232196.html?dids=49232196:49232196&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+07%2C+2000&author=&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=SCIENCE+NOTEBOOK&pqatl=google |journal=[[The Washington Post]] |date=February 7, 2000 |accessdate=February 23, 2010}}</ref>
==Selected publications== Greyson is co-author of ''Irreducible Mind: Toward a Psychology for the 21st Century'' (Rowman and Littlefield, 2007)<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.rowmanlittlefield.com/Catalog/SingleBook.shtml?command=Search&db=%5EDB%2FCATALOG.db&eqSKUdata=0742547922# |title=''Irreducible Mind'' |access-date=2018-11-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926212234/http://www.rowmanlittlefield.com/Catalog/SingleBook.shtml?command=Search&db=%5EDB%2FCATALOG.db&eqSKUdata=0742547922# |archive-date=2011-09-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and co-editor of ''The Handbook of Near-Death Experiences: Thirty Years of Investigation'' (Praeger, 2009).<ref>[http://www.healthsystem.virginia.edu/internet/personalitystudies/ Information about the Division of Perceptual Studies] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061006075133/http://www.healthsystem.virginia.edu/internet/personalitystudies/ |date=2006-10-06 }}</ref> He has written many journal articles on the subject of near-death experiences, and these include:
*{{cite journal | author = Greyson B | year = 2003 | title = Incidence and correlates of near-death experiences on a cardiac care unit | url =https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE38_Incidence-and-Correlates-of-NDEs-in-cardiac-care-unit.pdf | journal = Gen Hosp Psychiatry | volume = 25 | issue = | pages = 269–276 | doi=10.1016/s0163-8343(03)00042-2}} *{{cite journal | author = Greyson B | year = 2006 | title = Near-death experiences and spirituality | url =https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE46_spirituality-Zygon.pdf | journal = Zygon | volume = 41 | issue = | pages = 393–414 | doi=10.1111/j.1467-9744.2005.00745.x}} *{{cite journal | author = Greyson B | year = 2007 | title = Near-death experience: Clinical implications | url =https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE49_Near-Death-experiences-clinical-implications.pdf | journal = Rev Psiq Clin | volume = 34 | issue = | pages = 116–125 }} *{{cite journal | author = Greyson B | year = 2010 | title = Implications of near-death experiences for a post materialist psychology | url =https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE62_postmaterialist-PRS.pdf | journal = Psychol Relig Spirituality | volume = 2 | issue = | pages = 37–45 }} *{{Cite journal|pmid=15822242|year=2005|last1=Greyson|first1=B|title="False positive" claims of near-death experiences and "false negative" denials of near-death experiences|volume=29|issue=2|pages=145–55|doi=10.1080/07481180590906156|journal=Death studies|url=https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE43.pdf}} *{{Cite journal|author1=Greyson, B |author2=Ring, K. |title=The Life Changes Inventory – Revised|journal=Journal of Near-Death Studies|year= 2004|volume=23|pages=41–54|url=https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE41LCI-R-JNDS.pdf}} *{{Cite journal|author1=Greyson, B |author2=Liester, MB. |title= Auditory Hallucinations Following Near-Death Experiences|journal=Journal of Humanistic Psychology|year= 2004|volume=44|pages=320–336|doi=10.1177/0022167804266281|issue=3|url=https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE40_voices-JHP.pdf}} *{{Cite journal|pmid=15142300|year=2004|last1=Lange|first1=R|last2=Greyson|first2=B|last3=Houran|first3=J|title=A Rasch scaling validation of a 'core' near-death experience|volume=95|issue=Pt 2|pages=161–77|doi=10.1348/000712604773952403|journal=British journal of psychology (London, England : 1953)|url=https://med.virginia.edu/perceptual-studies/wp-content/uploads/sites/360/2017/01/NDE42_Rasch-BJP.pdf}}

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = CeDell Davis | image = | caption = | landscape = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Ellis CeDell Davis | birth_date = {{birth date|1926|6|9}} | birth_place = [[Helena, Arkansas]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|9|27|1926|6|9}} | death_place = [[Hot Springs, Arkansas]], U.S. | instrument = Vocals, guitar, harmonica | genre = [[Delta blues]] | occupation = Musician, songwriter | years_active = 1953–2017 | label = [[Fat Possum Records]] | associated_acts = [[Robert Nighthawk]] }}
'''Ellis CeDell Davis''' (June 9, 1926 – September 27, 2017) was an American [[blues]] guitarist and singer. He was most notable for his distinctive style of guitar playing. Davis played guitar using a butter knife in his fretting hand in a manner similar to [[slide guitar]], resulting in what ''The New York Times'' critic [[Robert Palmer (writer)|Robert Palmer]] called "a welter of metal-stress harmonic [[transient (acoustics)|transients]] and a singular tonal [[Plasticity (physics)|plasticity]]".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.arktimes.com/RockCandy/archives/2017/09/28/cedell-davis-remembered |title=CeDell Davis remembered |first=Stephanie |last=Smittle |newspaper=[[Arkansas Times]] |date=September 28, 2017}}</ref>
==Biography== Davis was born in [[Helena, Arkansas]], United States, where his family worked on a local plantation.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.oxfordamerican.org/magazine/item/1087-still-around-here |title=Still Around Here |date=February 2, 2017 |magazine=[[Oxford American]] |issue=95 |first=David |last=Ramsey}}</ref> He enjoyed music from a young age, playing harmonica and guitar with his childhood friends.
When he was 10, he suffered from severe [[polio]] which left him little control over his left hand and restricted use of his right.<ref name="amg">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=cedell-davis-mn0000740771 |tab=biography |pure_url=yes}} |title=CeDell Davis Biography |first=John |last=Bush |publisher=[[All Media Network]] |website=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=September 28, 2017}}</ref> He had been playing guitar prior to his polio and decided to continue despite his handicap, which led to his development of the butter knife method.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/22/us/the-blues-is-dying-in-the-place-it-was-born.html |title=The Blues Is Dying in the Place It Was Born |first=Rick |last=Bragg |author-link=Rick Bragg |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 22, 2001}}</ref>
Once he sufficiently mastered his variation on [[slide guitar]] playing, Davis began playing in various nightclubs across the [[Mississippi Delta]] area. He played with [[Robert Nighthawk]] for a ten-year period from 1953 to 1963. While playing in a club in 1957, a police raid caused the crowd to stampede over Davis. Both of his legs were broken in this incident and he was forced to use a wheelchair from that time onwards. The hardships resulting from his physical handicaps were a major influence on his lyrics and style of blues playing.
Davis moved to [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas]] in the early sixties and continued his artistic work. In recent times, Davis' music has been released by the [[Fat Possum Records]] label to much critical acclaim. His 1994 album, produced by [[Robert Palmer (writer)|Robert Palmer]], ''Feel Like Doin' Something Wrong'', received a 9.0 from [[Pitchfork Media]] who called it "timeless."
''The Best Of CeDell Davis'' (1995) was also released, with help from [[Col. Bruce Hampton and The Aquarium Rescue Unit]]. ''The Horror of It All'' followed in 1998. His album ''When Lightnin' Struck the Pine'', released in 2002, included work by musicians [[Peter Buck]], [[Barrett Martin]], [[Scott McCaughey]], and [[Alex Veley]].<ref name="amg"/>
Davis died on September 27, 2017, from complications of a heart attack in [[Hot Springs, Arkansas]], at the age of 91.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/01/obituaries/cedell-davis-bluesman-dies.html |title=CeDell Davis, Bluesman Who Played Guitar With a Knife, Dies at 91 |first=Jon |last=Pareles |author-link=Jon Pareles |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/sep/29/cedell-davis-20170929-1/?f=news-arkansas |title=Arkansas bluesman CeDell Davis dies at 91 |first=Sean |last=Clancy |newspaper=[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]] |date=September 29, 2017}}</ref>
==Discography== *''The Introduction To Living Country Blues USA'' - 1981 (1 track of the 12) *''Living Country Blues USA Vol. 5'' - 1982 (4 tracks of the 12 tracks) *''Living Country Blues USA Vol. 10'' - 1982 (1 track of the 13 tracks) *''Feel Like Doin' Something Wrong'' - 1994 *''The Best of CeDell Davis'' – 1995 *''The Horror Of It All'' – 1998 *''When Lightning Struck the Pine'' - 2002 *''Highway 61'' - 2003 *''Keep It to Yourself: Arkansas Blues, Vol. 1'' - 2004 (4 tracks of the 23 tracks) *''Last Man Standing'' - 2015 *''Even The Devil Gets The Blues'' - 2016
==Filmography== * ''Blues Back Home'' (1984) <ref>{{YouTube|id=TYtSiVkaKsY|title="CeDell Davis – Blues Back Home (1984)"}}</ref>
