Governor of [[Transvaal Colony|Transvaal]] }} [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] '''Garnet Joseph Wolseley, 1st Viscount Wolseley''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|KP|GCB|OM|GCMG|VD|PC}} (4 June 1833{{snd}}25 March 1913), was an [[Anglo-Irish]] officer in the [[British Army]]. He became one of the most influential and admired British generals after a series of successes in Canada, West Africa, and Egypt, followed by a central role in modernizing the British Army in promoting efficiency. He served in Burma, the [[Crimean War]], the [[Indian Mutiny]], China, Canada and widely throughout Africa—including his [[Anglo-Ashanti wars|Ashanti]] campaign (1873–1874) and the [[Nile Expedition]] against [[Mahdist War|Mahdist]] Sudan in 1884–85. Wolseley served as [[Commander-in-Chief of the Forces]] from 1895 to 1900. His reputation for efficiency led to the late 19th century English phrase "everything's all Sir Garnet", meaning, "All is in order."{{cite book|last1=Farmer|first1=John Stephen|last2=Henley|first2=W.E.|title=Slang and Its Analogues Past and Present: A Dictionary ... with Synonyms in English, French ... Etc. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JKRBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA215|accessdate=21 February 2013|year=1903|publisher=Harrison & Sons|page=215}} ==Early life and education == Lord Wolseley was born into a prominent [[Anglo-Irish people|Anglo-Irish]] family in [[Dublin]], the eldest son of [[Major (British Army)|Major]] Garnet Joseph Wolseley of the [[King's Own Scottish Borderers]] ([[25th Foot]]) and Frances Anne Wolseley (''née'' Smith). The Wolseleys were an ancient landed family in [[Wolseley, Staffordshire|Wolseley]], [[Staffordshire]], whose roots can be traced back a thousand years.{{cite news |title=Death of Lord Wolseley |work=[[The Times]] |publisher=The Times Digital Archive |page=7 |date=26 March 1913 }} Wolseley was born at Golden Bridge House, the seat of his mother's family. His paternal grandfather was Rev. William Wolseley, Rector of [[Tullycorbet]], and the third son of [[Sir Richard Wolseley, 1st Baronet]], who sat in the [[Irish House of Commons]] for [[Carlow Borough (Parliament of Ireland constituency)|Carlow]].{{cite book|title=Burke's Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Peerage, Baronetage and Knightage|date=1885|publisher=Burke's Peerage Limited|page=1425|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6u8_AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA1425|accessdate=28 June 2017|language=en}} The family seat was Mount Wolseley in [[County Carlow]].{{cite book|title=Complete Baronetage: Great Britain and Ireland, 1707-1800, and Jacobite, 1688-1788|date=1906|publisher=W. Pollard & Company, Limited|pages=356–357|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gMpKAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA356|accessdate=28 June 2017|language=en}} He had four younger sisters and two younger brothers, [[Frederick Wolseley]] (1837–1899) and Sir [[George Wolseley]] (1839–1921). Wolseley's father died in 1840 at age 62, leaving his widow and seven children to struggle on his Army pension. Unlike other boys in his class, Wolseley was not sent to England to attend [[Harrow School|Harrow]] or [[Eton College|Eton]], but was instead educated at a local school in Dublin. The family circumstance forced Wolseley to leave school at just 14, when he found work in a [[Surveying|surveyor]]'s office, which helped him bring in a salary and continue studying maths and geography.{{cite web|title=Field Marshal Garnet Joseph Wolseley, 1st Viscount Wolseley, KP, GCB, OM, GCMG, VD, PC.|url=http://www.irishmasonichistory.com/field-marshal-garnet-joseph-wolseley-1st-viscount-wolseley-kp-gcb-om-gcmg-vd-pc.html|website=Irish Masonic History and the Jewels of Irish Freemasonry|accessdate=28 June 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/36995?docPos=1|title=Garnet Wolseley, 1st Viscount Wolseley|publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|accessdate=26 February 2012}} Wolseley first considered a career in the church, but his financial situation meant that he would have needed a wealthy patron to support such an endeavor. Instead he sought a [[Officer (armed forces)|commission]] in the Army. Unable to afford [[Royal Military College, Sandhurst|Sandhurst]] or [[Sale of commissions|buying a commission]], Wolseley wrote to the [[Arthur Wellesley, 1st Duke of Wellington|Duke of Wellington]] for assistance. Wellington, then the [[Commander-in-Chief of the Forces]], promised to assist him when he turned 16. However, Wellington apparently overlooked him and did not respond to another letter sent when he was 17. Wolseley unsuccessfully appealed to his secretary, [[FitzRoy Somerset, 1st Baron Raglan|Lord Raglan]]. The British Army was then recovering from significant casualties in the latest [[Xhosa Wars|war in South Africa]], and Wolseley wrote Raglan, "I shall be prepared to start at the shortest notice, should your Lordship be pleased to appoint me to a regiment now at the seat of war." His mother then wrote the Duke again to appeal his case, and on 12 March 1852, the 18-year-old Wolseley was gazetted as an [[ensign (rank)|ensign]] in the [[Suffolk Regiment|12th Foot]],{{London Gazette|issue=21300|page=768|date=12 March 1852}} in recognition of his father's service. ==Second Burmese War== Just a month after he joined the [[Suffolk Regiment|12th Foot]], Wolseley transferred to the [[80th Regiment of Foot (Staffordshire Volunteers)|80th Foot]] on 13 April 1852,{{London Gazette|issue=21309|page=1058|date=13 April 1852|nolink=y}} with whom he served in the [[Second Anglo-Burmese War]].{{harvnb|Heathcote|p=311}} He was severely wounded when he was shot in the left thigh with a [[jingal]] bullet on 19 March 1853 in the attack on Donabyu, and was [[mentioned in despatches]]. Promoted to [[lieutenant]] on 16 May 1853 and invalided home, Wolseley transferred to the [[84th (York and Lancaster) Regiment of Foot|84th Regiment of Foot]] on 27 January 1854,{{London Gazette|issue=21515|page=232|date=27 January 1854|nolink=y}} and then to the [[90th Regiment of Foot (Perthshire Volunteers)|90th Light Infantry]],{{London Gazette|issue=21526|page=642|date=24 February 1854|nolink=y}} at that time stationed in [[Dublin]], on 24 February 1854. He was promoted to [[Captain (British Army and Royal Marines)|captain]] on 29 December 1854.{{London Gazette|issue=21645|page=4259|date=29 December 1854|nolink=y}} ==Crimea== Wolseley accompanied the regiment to [[Crimean War|the Crimea]], and landed at [[Balaklava]] in December 1854. He was selected to be an assistant [[Military engineer|engineer]], and attached to the [[Royal Engineers]] during the [[Crimean War#Siege of Sevastopol|Siege of Sevastopol]]. Wolseley served throughout the siege, where he was wounded at "the Quarries" on 7 June 1855, and again in the trenches on 30 August 1855, losing an eye. After the fall of [[Sevastopol]], Wolseley was employed on the [[quartermaster-general]]'s staff, assisting in the embarkation of the troops and supplies, and was one of the last British soldiers to leave the Crimea in July 1856. For his services he was twice mentioned in despatches, received the war medal with clasp, the 5th class of the French ''[[Légion d'honneur]]''{{London Gazette|issue=21909|page=2699|date=4 August 1856|nolink=y}} and the 5th class of the Turkish [[Order of the Medjidie]].{{EB1911|inline=y|wstitle=Wolseley, Garnet Joseph Wolseley, Viscount|volume=28|pages=777–778}}{{London Gazette|issue=22107|page=1264|date=2 March 1858|nolink=y}} Six months after joining the [[90th Foot]] at [[Aldershot]], he went with it in March 1857 to join the troops being despatched for the [[Second Opium War]]. Wolseley was embarked in the transport ''Transit'', which wrecked in the [[Bangka Strait|Strait of Banka]]. The troops were all saved, but with only their personal arms and minimal ammunition. They were taken to [[Singapore]], and from there dispatched to [[Calcutta]] on account of the [[Indian Mutiny]].{{cite web|url=http://www.timmonet.co.uk/html/body_wolseley.htm|title=A Victorian Army Hero|publisher=Timmonet|accessdate=26 February 2012}} ==Indian Mutiny of 1857== [[File:Felice Beato (British, born Italy - (Lieutenant-Colonel Wolsely, V.C.) - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|left|Lieutenant-Colonel Wolseley in India, by [[Felice Beato]], 1858–1859]] Wolseley distinguished himself at the [[relief of Lucknow]] under Sir [[Colin Campbell, 1st Baron Clyde|Colin Campbell]] in November 1857, and in the defence of the [[Alambagh]] position under [[Sir James Outram, 1st Baronet|Outram]], taking part in the actions of 22 December 1857, of 12 January 1858 and 16 January 1858, and also in the repulse of the grand attack of 21 February 1858. That March, he served at the final [[siege of Lucknow|siege]] and capture of Lucknow. He was then appointed deputy-assistant quartermaster-general on the staff of Sir [[Hope Grant]]'s [[Oudh]] division, and was engaged in all of the operations of the campaign, including the actions of [[Bari, India|Bari]], [[Purnia division#Sarsi|Sarsi]], [[Kanpur|Nawabganj]], the capture of [[Faizabad]], the passage of the [[Gumti]] and the action of [[Sultanpur, Uttar Pradesh|Sultanpur]]. In the autumn and winter of 1858–59 he took part in the [[Lalganj, Uttar Pradesh|Baiswara]], trans-[[Gogra]] and trans-[[West Rapti River|Rapti]] campaigns ending with the complete suppression of the [[rebellion]]. For his services he was frequently mentioned in dispatches, and having received the [[Indian Mutiny Medal|Mutiny medal]] and clasp, he was promoted to brevet [[major]] on 24 March 1858{{London Gazette|issue=22117|page=1571|date=24 March 1858|nolink=y}} and to brevet [[lieutenant-colonel]] on 26 April 1859.{{London Gazette|issue=22255|page=1727|date=26 April 1859|nolink=y}} Wolseley continued to serve on Sir Hope Grant's staff in Oudh, and when Grant was nominated to the [[Chain of command|command]] of the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|British]] troops in the [[Second Opium War|Anglo-French expedition to China]] of 1860, accompanied him as the deputy-assistant quartermaster-general. He was present at the action at [[Sin Ho District|Sin-ho]], the capture of [[Tanggu District|Tang-ku]], the storming of the [[Taku Forts]], the Occupation of [[Tianjin|Tientsin]], the Battle of [[Xilin County|Pa-to-cheau]] and the entry into [[Peking]] (during which the destruction of the [[Chinese people|Chinese]] [[Chinese Emperor|Imperial]] [[Old Summer Palace]] was begun). He assisted in the re-embarkation of the troops before the winter set in. He was Mentioned, yet again, in Dispatches, and for his services received the medal and two clasps. On his return home he published the ''Narrative of the War with China'' in 1860.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Narrative_of_the_War_with_China_in_1860.html?id=N1DRr0hocw8C&redir_esc=y |title=Narrative of the War with China|publisher=BiblioBazaar|year=2008|accessdate=26 February 2012}} He was given the substantive rank of [[major]] on 15 February 1861.{{London Gazette|issue=22480|page=654|date=15 February 1861|nolink=y}} ==Canada== [[File:Viscount Garnet Joseph Wolseley.jpeg|thumb|right|Field Marshal Viscount Wolseley|250px]] In November 1861, Wolseley was one of the special service officers sent to [[Canada]] in connection with the [[Trent Affair|''Trent'' incident]]. In 1862, shortly after the [[Battle of Antietam]], Wolseley took leave from his military duties and went to investigate the [[American Civil War]]. He befriended [[Confederate States of America|Southern]] sympathizers in [[Maryland]], who found him passage into [[Virginia]] with a [[blockade runner]] across the [[Potomac River]]. There he met with the Generals [[Robert E. Lee]], [[James Longstreet]] and [[Stonewall Jackson]]. He also provided an analysis on Lieutenant General [[Nathan Bedford Forrest]]. The ''[[New Orleans Picayune]]'' (10 April 1892) published Wolseley's ten-page portrayal of Forrest, which condensed much of what was written about him by biographers of the time. This work appeared in the ''Journal of the Southern Historical Society'' in the same year, and is commonly cited today. Wolseley addressed Forrest's role at the [[Battle of Fort Pillow]] near [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]], [[Tennessee]] in April, 1864 in which [[African-American|black]] [[United States Colored Troops|USCT]] troops and [[White people|white]] officers were alleged by some to have been slaughtered after [[Fort Pillow, Tennessee|Fort Pillow]] had been conquered. Wolseley wrote, "I do not think that the fact that one-half of the small garrison of a place taken by assault was either killed or wounded evinced any very unusual bloodthirstiness on the part of the assailants."''United Service Magazine'', London, 1892, April and May issues Wolseley returned to Canada where he became a brevet [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|colonel]] on 5 June 1865 and Assistant Quartermaster-General in Canada with effect from the same date.{{London Gazette|issue=22992|page=3579|date=18 July 1865|nolink=y}} He was actively employed the following year in the defence of Canada from [[Fenian raids]] launched from the [[United States]]. He was appointed Deputy Quartermaster-General in Canada on 1 October 1867.{{London Gazette|issue=23278|page=4045|date=19 July 1867|nolink=y}} In 1869 his ''Soldiers' Pocket Book for Field Service'' was published,{{harvnb|Heathcote|p=312}} and has since run through many editions. In 1870, he successfully commanded the [[Wolseley Expedition|Red River Expedition]] to establish Canadian [[sovereignty]] over the [[Northwest Territories]] and [[Manitoba]]. Manitoba had entered [[Canadian Confederation]] when the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] transferred its control of western Canada to the government of the Dominion of Canada. British and Canadian authorities ignored the pre-existing Government of Assiniboia and botched negotiations with its replacement, the [[Métis people (Canada)|''Métis'']]'s rebel Provisional Government headed by [[Louis Riel]]. The campaign to put down the rebellion was made difficult by the poor communications at the time. [[Fort Garry]] (now [[Winnipeg, Manitoba|Winnipeg]]), the [[Capital (political)|capital]] of [[Manitoba]] was a small centre separated from Ontario by the rocks and forests of the Canadian Shield region. The easiest route to Fort Garry that did not pass through the United States was through a network of rivers and lakes extending for six-hundred miles from [[Lake Superior]], infrequently traversed by non-[[Aboriginal peoples in Canada|aboriginal]]s, and where no supplies were obtainable. The admirable arrangements made and the careful organization of the transport reflected great credit to the commander (Wolseley), who upon his return home was made a [[Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George]] on 22 December 1870,{{London Gazette|issue=23690|page=5873|date=23 December 1870|nolink=y}} and a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] on 13 March 1871.{{London Gazette|issue=23715|page=1378|date=14 March 1871|nolink=y}} Appointed assistant [[adjutant-general]] at the [[War Office]] in 1871 he furthered the [[Cardwell reforms|Cardwell schemes of army reform]]. ==Ashanti== [[File:Garnet Joseph Wolseley, 1874.png|thumb|250px|Wolseley in 1874, from the ''[[Illustrated London News]]'']] In 1873, Wolseley commanded the expedition to [[Ashanti Empire|the Ashanti]], and, having made all his arrangements at the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] before the arrival of the troops in January 1874, was able to complete the campaign in two months, and re-embark them for home before the unhealthy season began. This campaign made him a household name in Britain. At the [[Battle of Amoaful]] on 31 January of that year Wolseley's expedition faced the numerically superior Chief Amankwatia's army in a four-hour battle. They advanced through thick bush in loose squares, and after five days' fighting, ending with the [[Battle of Ordashu]], entered the capital [[Kumasi]], which he burned. He received the thanks of both houses of [[Parliament of England|Parliament]] and a grant of £25,000, was promoted to brevet [[major-general]] for distinguished service in the field on 1 April 1874,{{London Gazette|issue=24082|page=1924|date=31 March 1874|nolink=y}} received the medal and clasp and was made [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of St Michael and St George]] on 31 March 1874,{{London Gazette|issue=24083|page=1971|date=3 April 1874|nolink=y}} and a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the Bath]]. The [[freedom of the city]] of [[City of London|London]] was conferred upon him with a sword of honour, and he was made honorary DCL of [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] and LL.D of [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] universities. On his return home he was appointed [[inspector-general]] of [[Auxiliaries|auxiliary forces]] with effect from 1 April 1874;{{London Gazette|issue=24085|page=2061|date=10 April 1874|nolink=y}} however, in consequence of the indigenous unrest in [[Colony of Natal|Natal]], he was sent to that colony as governor and general-commanding on 24 February 1875.{{London Gazette|issue=24184|page=810|date=26 February 1875|nolink=y}} Wolseley accepted a seat on the [[Council of India]] in November 1876 and was promoted to the substantive rank of [[major-general]] on 1 October 1877.{{London Gazette|issue=24508|page=5460|date=2 October 1877|nolink=y}} Having been promoted to brevet [[lieutenant-general]] on 25 March 1878,{{London Gazette|issue=24574|page=2638|date=19 April 1878|nolink=y}} he went as high-commissioner to the newly acquired possession of [[Cyprus]] on 12 July 1878,{{London Gazette|issue=24605|page=4154|date=16 July 1878|nolink=y}} and in the following year to South Africa to supersede [[Frederic Thesiger, 2nd Baron Chelmsford|Lord Chelmsford]] in command of the forces in the [[Zulu War]], and as governor of [[Colony of Natal|Natal]] and the [[Transvaal Colony|Transvaal]] and the [[High Commissioner]] of [[Southern Africa]]. Wolseley with his 'Ashanti Ring' of adherents was sent to [[Durban]]. But on arrival in July, he found that the war in [[Zulu Kingdom|Zululand]] was practically over, and, after effecting a temporary settlement, he went on to the Transvaal. He was promoted to brevet [[general]] while serving in South Africa on 4 June 1879.{{London Gazette|issue=24730|page=3731|date=3 June 1879|nolink=y}} Having reorganized the administration there and reduced the powerful [[tribal chief|King]], [[Sekhukhune]], to submission, he returned to London in May 1880. For his services in South Africa he was awarded the [[South Africa Medal (1877)|South Africa Medal]] with clasp, and was advanced to [[Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Bath]] on 19 June 1880.{{London Gazette|issue=24857|page=3587|date=22 June 1880|nolink=y}} Finally as if to signify a meteoric rise in Imperial esteem he was appointed [[Quartermaster-General to the Forces]] on 1 July 1880.{{London Gazette|issue=24838|page=2727|date=27 April 1880|nolink=y}} ==Egypt and Commander-in-Chief== [[File:Garnet wolseley cartoon.png|thumb|left|250px|1882 [[caricature]] from [[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]]] On 1 April 1882, Wolseley was appointed [[Adjutant-General to the Forces]],{{London Gazette|issue=25084|page=1131|date=14 March 1882|nolink=y}} and, in August of that year, given command of the British forces in [[Egypt]] under [[Khedive Tewfik]] to suppress the [[Urabi Revolt]].{{harvnb|Heathcote|p=313}} Having seized the [[Suez Canal]], he then disembarked his troops at [[Ismailia]] and, after a very short campaign, completely defeated [[Ahmed 'Urabi|Urabi Pasha]] at the [[Battle of Tel el-Kebir]], thereby suppressing yet another rebellion. For his services, he was promoted to the substantive rank of [[general (British Army)|general]] on 18 November{{London Gazette|issue=25169|page=5173|date=17 November 1882|nolink=y}} and raised to the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom|peerage]] as '''Baron Wolseley''', of [[Cairo]] and of [[Wolseley, Staffordshire|Wolseley]] in the County of Stafford. He also received the thanks of Parliament and [[Egypt Medal|the Egypt Medal]] with clasp;{{London Gazette|issue=25170|page=5195|date=21 November 1882|nolink=y}} the [[Order of Osmanieh]], First Class, as bestowed by the [[Khedive]];{{London Gazette|issue=25168|page=5106|date=17 November 1882|nolink=y}} and the more dubious accolade of a composition in his honour by [[poetaster]] [[William Topaz McGonagall]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mcgonagall-online.org.uk/gems/the-battle-of-tel-el-kebir|title=The Battle of Tel-el-Kebir|publisher=Mcgonagall|accessdate=16 September 2015}} On 1 September 1884, Wolseley was again called away from his duties as adjutant-general, to command the [[Nile Expedition]] for the relief of [[Charles George Gordon|General Gordon]] and the besieged garrison at [[Khartoum]]. Wolseley's unusual strategy was to take an expedition by boat up the Nile and then to cross the desert to Khartoum, while the naval boats went on to Khartoum.{{London Gazette|issue=25394|page=4040|date=9 September 1884|nolink=y}} The expedition arrived too late; Khartoum had been taken, and Gordon was dead. In the spring of 1885, complications with [[Imperial Russia]] over the [[Panjdeh Incident]] occurred, and the withdrawal of that particular expedition followed. For his services there, he received two clasps to his Egyptian medal, the thanks of Parliament, and on 28 September 1885 was created '''Viscount Wolseley''', of Wolseley in the County of Stafford,{{London Gazette|issue=25514|page=4515|date=25 September 1885|nolink=y}}{{cite book|last1=Cokayne|first1=George Edward|title=Complete Peerage of England, Scotland, Ireland, Great Britain and the United Kingdom, Extant, Extinct, Or Dormant|date=1898|publisher=G. Bell & sons|page=195|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6K8KAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA195|accessdate=29 June 2017|language=en}} and a [[Knight of the Order of St Patrick]]. At the invitation of the [[Queen Victoria|Queen]], the Wolseley family moved from their former home at 6 [[Hill Street, London]] to the much grander [[Ranger's House]] in [[Greenwich]] in autumn 1888.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Iv4m19wI0WYC&pg=PT229&lpg=PT229&dq=ranger%27s+house+garnet+wolseley&source=bl&ots=E4CnjMWjx_&sig=yWhBkrV5mr__bUdcY0_7wyja5UE&hl=en&sa=X&ei=EdbMU6XaG6aI7Aaow4HADQ&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=ranger's%20house%20garnet%20wolseley&f=false|title=The Master, the Modern Major General, and His Clever Wife: Henry James's Letters to Field Marshal Lord Wolseley and Lady Wolseley, 1878–1913|first=Henry|last=James|publisher=University of Virginia Press|year=2012}} Wolseley continued at the War Office as [[Adjutant-General to the Forces]] until 1890, when he became [[Commander-in-Chief, Ireland]]. He was promoted to be a [[Field marshal (United Kingdom)|field marshal]] on 26 May 1894,{{London Gazette|issue=26516|page=3117|date=26 May 1894|nolink=y}} and appointed by the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Her Majesty's Government|government]] to succeed the [[Prince George, Duke of Cambridge|Duke of Cambridge]] as [[Commander-in-Chief of the Forces]] on 1 November 1895.{{London Gazette|issue=26676|page=5923|date=1 November 1895|nolink=y}} This was the position to which his great experience in the field and his previous signal success at the War Office itself had fully entitled him, but it was increasingly irrelevant. Field Marshal Viscount Wolseley's powers in that office were, however, limited by a new [[Order in Council]], and after holding the appointment for over five years, he handed over the command-in-chief to his fellow field marshal, [[Frederick Roberts, 1st Earl Roberts|Earl Roberts]], on 3 January 1901.{{London Gazette|issue=27263|page=83|date=4 January 1901|nolink=y}} He had also suffered from a serious illness in 1897, from which he never fully recovered. The unexpectedly large force required for the initial phase of the [[Second Boer War]], was mainly furnished by means of the system of reserves Wolseley had originated—but the new conditions at the War Office were not to his liking. The fiasco now called [[Black Week]] culminated in his dismissal over Christmastide 1900. Upon being released from responsibilities he brought the whole subject before the [[House of Lords]] in a speech.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1901/mar/04/war-office-administration-duties-of#S4V0090P0_19010304_HOL_56|title=War Office Administration – Duties of Commander-in-Chief|publisher=Hansard|date=4 March 1901|accessdate=26 February 2012}} Lord Wolseley was [[Gold Stick and Silver Stick|Gold Stick in Waiting]] to Queen Victoria and took part in the funeral procession following the death of Queen Victoria in February 1901.{{London Gazette|issue=27316 |supp=1|page=3552|date=22 May 1901|nolink=y}} He also served as Gold Stick in Waiting to [[Edward VII|King Edward]] during his [[Coronation of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra|coronation]] in August 1902.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Coronation |day_of_week=Thursday |date=31 July 1902 |page_number=8 |issue=36834| }} ===Honorific and royal appointments=== [[File:Arms of Viscount Wolseley.svg|thumb|Arms of Viscount Wolseley: ''Argent, a talbot passant gules, a mullet, for difference'']] In early 1901, Lord Wolseley was appointed by [[Edward VII|King Edward]] to lead a special diplomatic mission to announce the King's accession to the governments of [[Austria-Hungary]], [[Kingdom of Romania|Romania]], [[Kingdom of Serbia|Serbia]], the [[Ottoman Empire]] and [[Kingdom of Greece (Glücksburg)|Greece]].{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The King – the special Embassies |day_of_week=Saturday |date=23 March 1901 |page_number=12 |issue=36410}} During his visit to [[Constantinople]], the Sultan presented him with the [[Order of Osmanieh]] set in brilliants.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The King´s accession |day_of_week=Friday |date=12 April 1901 |page_number=3 |issue=36427}} He was among the original recipients of the [[Order of Merit]] in the [[1902 Coronation Honours]] list published on 26 June 1902,{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Coronation Honours |day_of_week=Thursday |date=26 June 1902 |page_number=5 |issue=36804| }} and received the order from King Edward VII at [[Buckingham Palace]] on 8 August 1902.{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Court Circular |day_of_week=Saturday |date=9 August 1902 |page_number=6 |issue=36842| }}{{London Gazette|issue=27470|page=5679|date=2 September 1902| |nolink=y}} For his service with the [[Volunteer Force (Great Britain)|Volunteer Force]], he was awarded the [[Volunteer Decoration|Volunteer Officers' Decoration]] on 11 August 1903.{{London Gazette|issue=27586|page=5078|date=11 August 1903|nolink=y}} He was also honorary colonel of the 23rd [[Middlesex Regiment]] from 12 May 1883,{{London Gazette|issue=25229|page=2500|date=11 May 1883|nolink=y}} honorary colonel of the Queen's Rifle Volunteer Brigade, the [[Royal Scots]] (Lothian Regiment) from 24 April 1889,{{London Gazette|issue=25926|page=2294|date=23 April 1889|nolink=y}} colonel of the [[Royal Horse Guards]] from 29 March 1895{{London Gazette|issue=26624|page=2774|date=14 May 1895|nolink=y}} and colonel-in-chief of the [[Royal Irish Regiment (1684–1922)|Royal Irish Regiment]] from 20 July 1898.{{London Gazette|issue=26988|page=4354|date=19 July 1898|nolink=y}} In retirement, he was a member of the council of the [[Union-Castle Steamship Line|Union-Castle Steamship Company]].{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=New Castle liner Walmer Castle |day_of_week=Saturday |date=15 March 1902 |page_number=11 |issue=36716| }} ==Channel Tunnel== [[File:LionCannotFaceTheCrowingOfCock.png|thumb|left|250px|General Wolseley riding on the fleeing lion. Published in the American Humor Magazine "Puck" (approx. 1885).]] Wolseley was deeply opposed to [[Edward Watkin|Sir Edward Watkin]]'s attempt to build a [[Channel Tunnel]]. He gave evidence to a parliamentary commission that the construction might be "calamitous for England", he added that "No matter what fortifications and defences were built, there would always be the peril of some continental army seizing the tunnel exit by surprise." Various contrivances to satisfy his objections were put forward including looping the line on a viaduct from the [[White Cliffs of Dover|Cliffs of Dover]] and back into them, so that the connection could be bombarded at will by the [[Royal Navy]]. For a combination of reasons over 100 years were to pass before a permanent link was made.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1929/jan/24/proposed-channel-tunnel |title=Proposed Channel Tunnel|publisher= Hansard|date= 24 January 1929|accessdate=25 February 2012}} ==Personal life and death== [[File:Ex-libris - Garnet Wolseley, 1st Viscount Wolseley.jpg|thumb|left|250px|''Ex ibris'' with his coat of arms]] Wolseley was married in 1867 to Louisa (1843–1920), the daughter of Mr. A. Erskine. His only child, [[Frances Garnet Wolseley, 2nd Viscountess Wolseley|Frances]] (1872–1936) was an author and founded the College for Lady Gardeners at [[Glynde]]. She was [[Beneficiary|heiress]] to the viscountcy under special remainder, but it became extinct after her death. In his later years, Lord and Lady Wolseley lived in a [[grace-and-favour]] apartment at [[Hampton Court Palace]]. He and his wife were wintering at Villa Tourrette, [[Menton]] on the [[French Riviera]], where he fell ill with influenza and died on 26 March 1913. He was buried on 31 March 1913 in the crypt of [[St Paul's Cathedral]], to music played by the band of the 2nd Battalion [[Royal Irish Regiment (1684–1922)|Royal Irish Regiment]], of which he was the first [[Colonel-in-Chief]].{harvnb|Heathcote|p=314}}''The Campaigns and History of the Royal Irish Regiment'' by Brigadier-General Stannus Geoghegan CB, Blackwood, Edinburgh and London, 1911, updated 1927 ==Legacy== [[File:Wolseley statue, Horse Guards Parade.jpg|thumb|right|[[Equestrian statue of the Viscount Wolseley|Equestrian statue of Field Marshal Lord Wolseley]] by Goscombe John, [[Horse Guards Parade]] (2008)]] There is an [[Equestrian statue of the Viscount Wolseley|equestrian statue of Wolseley]] in [[Horse Guards Parade]] in London. This was sculpted by [[Goscombe John|Sir William Goscombe John R.A.]]{{cite book | title=Discovering London Statues and Monuments | publisher=Osprey Publishing | author=Baker, Margaret | year=2008 | page=18 | isbn=0747804958}} and erected in 1920.{{cite web | url=http://www.secret-london.co.uk/Horse_Guards.html | title=Horse Guards Parade | publisher=Secret London | accessdate=29 March 2013}} [[Wolseley Barracks]], at [[London, Ontario|London]], [[Ontario]], is a Canadian [[military base]] (now officially known as [[CFB London|ASU London]]), established in 1886. It is on the site of ''Wolseley Hall'', the first building constructed by a [[Canadian Government]] specifically to house an element of the newly created [[Permanent Active Militia|Permanent Force]]. ''Wolseley Barracks'' has been continuously occupied by the [[Canadian Army]] since its creation, and has always housed some element of ''[[The Royal Canadian Regiment]]''. At present, Wolseley Hall is occupied by the [[Royal Canadian Regiment Museum]] and ''the Regiment's'' 4th Battalion, among other [[leasehold estate|tenant]]s.{{CRHP|14341|Wolseley Barracks|29 July 2011}} The white pith helmet still worn as part of the full-dress uniform of the RCR (pictured in the caricature above from ''Punch'') is known as a Wolseley helmet.{{cite web|url=http://www.naval-military-press.com/wolseley-helmet-in_pictures-from-omdurman-to-el-alamein.html|title=Wolseley Helmet in pictures From Omdurman to El Alamein|publisher=Naval & Military Press|accessdate=25 February 2012}}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Wolseley is also a Senior Boys house at the [[Duke of York's Royal Military School]].{{cite web |url=http://www.doyrms.com/structure.html |title=Structure |publisher=Duke of York's Royal Military School |accessdate=25 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130819061447/http://www.doyrms.com/structure.html |archivedate=19 August 2013 |df=dmy }} [[File:Colwich, Staffordshire - St Michael and All Angels Church - Lord Wolseley memorial.JPG|thumb|left|Lord Wolseley memorial at St Michael and All Angels Church in [[Colwich, Staffordshire]]]] Field Marshal Lord Wolseley is commemorated by a tablet at St Michael and All Angels Church in [[Colwich, Staffordshire|Colwich]], [[Staffordshire]], a short distance from [[Shugborough Hall]] and Wolseley Park at Colwich, near [[Rugeley]]. The church was the burial place of the [[Wolseley baronets]] of Wolseley Park, the ancestral home of the Wolseley family.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/en-443128-parish-church-of-st-michael-and-all-ange|title=Parish Church of St Michael and All Angels, Colwich|publisher=British Listed Buildings|accessdate=1 October 2012}} [[W. S. Gilbert]], of the musical partnership [[Gilbert and Sullivan]], deliberately modelled the character of Major-General Stanley in the [[operetta]] ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' on Wolseley, as did [[George Grossmith]], the actor who first created the role in the opening theatrical run.{{sfn|Bradley|p=220}} In another of Gilbert and Sullivan's operettas, ''[[Patience (opera)|Patience]]'', Colonel Calverley praises Wolseley in the phrase: "Skill of Sir Garnet in thrashing a cannibal".{{cite web|url=http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/patience/webop/pat03.html|title=Patience Web Opera|work=diamond.boisestate.edu|accessdate=17 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303193410/http://diamond.boisestate.edu/gas/patience/webop/pat03.html|archive-date=3 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[File:Sir Garnet pub 1883 drawing.jpg|thumb|250px|The Sir Garnet pub in 1883]] The residential areas of [[Wolseley, Winnipeg|Wolseley]] in [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada, located in the west central part of the city{{cite web|url=http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/features/walkingtours/wolseley/index.shtml |title=An Historical Walking Tour of Wolseley (Winnipeg)|publisher=The Manitoba Historical Society|accessdate=25 February 2012}} and of [[Wolseley, Saskatchewan|Wolseley]] in [[Saskatchewan]], Canada are named after him{{cite web|url=http://www.dunncanada.com/harrowsmith.shtml|title=Wolseley: My Kind of Town|publisher=Harrowsmith Country Life|date=April 2000|accessdate=25 February 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220160149/http://www.dunncanada.com/harrowsmith.shtml|archivedate=20 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} The town of [[Wolseley, Western Cape]], South Africa, is named after Sir Garnet Joseph Wolseley. It was established on the farm Goedgevonden in 1875 and attained municipal status in 1955; prior to this it was known as Ceres Road."Dictionary of Southern African Place Names" P.E.Raper) The Sir Garnet pub in the centre of [[Norwich]], overlooking the historic market place and city hall, is named after Field Marshal Lord Wolseley. The pub opened in about 1861 and adopted the name Sir Garnet Wolseley in 1874, changed after a brief closing (2011–12) to Sir Garnet.{{cite web |url=http://www.vintagenorwich.co.uk/2012/05/a-new-life-for-sir-garnet/ |title=A New Life for Sir Garnet |author=Gemma |date=30 May 2012 |work=Vintage Norwich |accessdate=2 May 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.norwich-market.org.uk/Pubs/sir_garnet_wolseley.shtm |title=Sir Garnet Wolseley |work=Norwich Market |publisher=Norwich Heritage Projects |accessdate=2 May 2014}}{{cite web |url=http://www.thesirgarnet.co.uk/about/ |title=About the Sir Garnet |publisher=The Sir Garnet |accessdate=2 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140503022510/http://www.thesirgarnet.co.uk/about/ |archivedate=3 May 2014 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://www.eveningnews24.co.uk/news/norwich_market_place_to_get_the_sir_garnet_wolseley_pub_back_but_with_a_different_name_1_1425314 |title=Norwich market place to get the Sir Garnet Wolseley pub back – but with a different name |author=Bale, David |work=Norwich Evening News |date=29 June 2012 |accessdate=29 March 2013}}{{clear}} Wolseley's uniforms, Field Marshal's baton and souvenirs from his various campaigns are held in the collections of the [[Glenbow Museum]] in Calgary, Alberta, Canada. Wolseley maintained a deep interest in notable individuals in Early Modern European history, and collected items related to many of them (for example, a box from [[Sir Francis Drake]], a watch related to [[Oliver Cromwell]], a funerary badge for [[Admiral Horatio Nelson]] and General [[James Wolfe]]'s snuff box). These are also held in the collection.{{cite web|url=http://www.glenbow.org/collections/museum/military/famous.cfm |title=Collections & Research > Museum Collections > Military & Mounted Police > Famous People & Battles |publisher=Glenbow |date= |accessdate=2017-05-22}} In recognition of his success, an expression arose: "'''all Sir Garnet'''" meaning; that everything is in good order.Eric Partridge, ''A Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English'', (1961){{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/jul/18/army-cut-not-all-sir-garnet-editorial |title=Army cuts: Not 'All Sir Garnet' |author=Guardian editorial board |date=18 July 2011 |work=The Guardian |quote=The Victorian byword for a smart operation of any kind was 'All Sir Garnet'...|accessdate=18 February 2013}} ==Selected publications by Viscount Wolseley== *{{cite journal|title=General Lee|journal=Macmillan's Magazine|date=March 1887|volume=55|issue=329|pages=321–331|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=njp.32101038084586;view=1up;seq=173}} *{{cite book|title=Narrative of the war with China in 1860; revision.text:
{{POV-check|date=July 2018}}
[[File:Qulliq 1999-04-01.jpg|thumb|An Inuit woman tending a [[kudlik]].]] The [[Inuit]] are the most widespread and perhaps the best known [[Indigenous peoples|aboriginal people]] on earth.<ref name="Morrison">Morrison, David. 2004. Inuit Culture. In ''The Oxford Companion to Canadian Histor''y. Gerald Hallowell, ed. Oxford: Oxford University Press.</ref> As a very large indigenous group inhabiting the [[Arctic]] regions of [[Alaska]], [[Canada]], [[Greenland]], and [[Russia]], the Inuit exhibit many variations in cultural practices and customs.
In Inuit communities, the women play a crucial role in the survival of the group. The responsibilities faced by '''Inuit women''' were considered equally as important as those faced by the men. Because of this, the women were given due respect, but are not given an equal share of influence or power.<ref name="Billson" />
Recent modernization and urbanization has transformed traditional [[Inuit culture]] and influenced the role of women within the culture. These changes include both positive and negative impacts on the overall well-being of Inuit women.<ref name="McElroy" />
==Role in society== ===Family structure and marriage=== [[File:Madonna of the North.jpg|thumb|"Madonna of the North" (Inuit woman with child on back, {{circa|1912}})]] In Inuit culture, [[marriage]] was not a choice, but a necessity. Inuit men and women needed each other to survive. Married couples had to work together to overcome nearly impossible living conditions. Because every individual had to rely on a partner to survive, marriages were often arranged at birth to ensure the survival of the family. [[Love marriage]]s, or choice marriages, existed, but these were all but [[arranged marriage|arranged]] because there were usually few eligible partners. A young woman was eligible for marriage after [[puberty]], but a man had to prove he was efficient enough in hunting to support a family before he could marry.<ref name="McElroy" />
Inuit marriages rarely included large ceremonies; couples were often considered married after the birth of their first child. There were [[Monogamy|monogamous]] and [[Polygamy|polygamous]] marriages, but [[polygyny]] was rare because few men could afford to support multiple wives.<ref name="Morrison" /> Families exchanged gifts before marriages, but no official [[bride price]] or [[dowry]] was paid. Although men were considered the head of the family, both genders could demand a divorce.<ref name="Lowry">Lowry, Shannon. 1994. Natives of the Far North: Alaska’s Vanishing Culture Through the Eye of Edward Sheriff Curtis. Pennsylvania: Stackpole Books.</ref> However, divorce was frowned upon because it was bad for the family and the community as a whole.<ref name="Billson">Billson, Janet Mancini and Kyra Mancini. 2007. ''Inuit Women: Their Powerful Spirit in a Century of Change''. Maryland: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, Inc.</ref>
Spouses were sometimes traded or exchanged, and women had some say in this process. This was a common alternative to divorce because neither family would be without a component vital to its survival — a mother and a wife. In Inuit culture, the family was typically represented by a ''[[kudlik]]'' (lamp) or a hearth, which was the property and responsibility of the wife. This lamp had significant symbolic meaning in the family, the community, and the culture.<ref name="LeMoine">LeMoine, Genevieve. 2003. Woman of the House: Gender, Architecture, and Ideology in Dorset Prehistory. Arctic Anthropology 40(1): 121–138.</ref>
===Food production and preparation=== [[Hunting]] and [[fishing]] were the primary sources of food for the Inuit people, and men were traditionally responsible for these duties. Women's duties included gathering other sources of food, such as eggs and berries, and preparing the food the hunters brought back. [[Pinniped|Seals]], [[walrus]], [[whale]]s and [[Reindeer|caribou]] were the most common targets of Inuit hunters. Animals killed by the hunters needed to be butchered and frozen quickly, before they went bad or froze before being butchered. Women were traditionally responsible for the butchering, skinning, and cooking of animals taken by the hunters.<ref name="Friesen">Friesen, Max T. 1999. Resource Structure, Scalar Stress, and the Development of Inuit Social Organization. ''World Archaeology'' 31(1): 21–37.</ref>
In Inuit culture, it was believed that the women's respect for the animals killed during hunting trips, and subsequent care when butchering them, would ensure successful hunts.<ref name="LeMoine" /> Food, as well as other resources, were often shared throughout the community as needed. Women were in charge of the distribution of food to families in the community.<ref name="LeMoine" />
The Inuit moved with the seasons to maximize their chances of a successful hunt; their entire families often moved with them.<ref name="Morrison" /> Because of this, tools and other items used by the Inuit for hunting and food preparation had to be light and easily transported. Among some Inuit groups this led to the development of complex tools such as light and powerful metal [[harpoon]]s and wood stoves, which were being used by the late 1800s.<ref name="Labrador">Labrador, Nachvak and Kongu Labrador. 2006. A New Design: When Europeans Met Inuit in Labrador, Home and Hearth Were Reshaped. The Beaver: Exploring Canada’s History 86(3): 26–29.</ref>
===Children, reproduction, and motherhood=== [[Childbirth]] and [[childcare]] were two of the most important responsibilities for an Inuit woman. Inuit parents showed a very high level of warmth and affection to their children. Inuit children usually began to contribute to the family and community by the age of 12 through activities like picking berries and hunting small game. During this period, they learned skills from their parents through close observation. Learning through observation was the chosen method because it was not practical for children to practice their skills by sewing valuable skins or accompanying men on important hunting trips.<ref name="McElroy" />
Women raised boys and girls. Men taught boys certain skills, such as hunting, and women taught girls certain skills, such as sewing. Children were named after family members, often ones who recently died. There were no boys and girls names in Inuit culture, so it was common for a girl to have the name of her grandfather, for example.<ref name="Lowry" />
Children were taught at a young age to listen to their parents and respect their elders, and were treated with more autonomy than non-Inuit children.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://kugluktukhighschool.ca/the-inuit-way-a-guide-to.pdf|title=The Inuit Way: A Guide to Inuit Culture|last=|first=|publisher=Pauktuutit|year=2006|isbn=|edition=Revised|location=Ottawa, Ontario|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> Over disciplining a child was seen as counter productive so children were rarely punished for transgressions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://tradition-orale.ca/english/pdf/Childrearing-Practices-E.pdf|title=Interviewing Inuit Elders: Childrearing Practices|last=Ekho|first=Naqi|last2=Ottokie|first2=Uqsuralik|publisher=Nunavut Arctic College|year=2000|isbn=1896204376|editor-last=Briggs|editor-first=Jean|location=Iqaluit, Nunavut|pages=|quote=|via=}}</ref> Learning was regarded as a partnership between child and adult, with children being more guided through life than directly taught or lectured.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.nccah-ccnsa.ca/docs/fact%20sheets/child%20and%20youth/Inuit%20caring%20EN%20web.pdf|title=Inunnguiniq: Caring for children the Inuit way|last=|first=|publisher=National Collaborating Centre for Aboriginal Health|year=2009–2010|isbn=|location=|pages=2|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Adoption was very common in Inuit culture, and it was often very informal. Unwanted babies, or babies a family could not support, could be offered to another family. If the other family accepted, the adoption was complete.<ref name="Kent">Kent, Heather. 2000. MDs Get Crash Course in Inuit Culture as Young Patients Arrive in Ottawa. Canadian Medical Association Journal 162(10): 1481.</ref>
[[Infanticide]] was common when conditions were desperate and the group was threatened by starvation.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=8M8aihnBACwC&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=inuit+infanticide&source=web&ots=Gr1djRu8yL&sig=quPfEmRFgaVP4T86FdT0_5WO1N0&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result Inuit Women: Their Powerful Spirit in a Century of Change] By Janet Mancini Billson</ref><ref>{{cite news | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1200/is_n22_v146/ai_15952600/pg_1?tag=artBody;col1 | work=Science News | first=Bruce | last=Bower | title=Female infanticide: northern exposure – Intuit may have killed one out of every five female babies between 1880 and 1940 – Brief Article | year=1994}}</ref> A mother abandoned an infant in hopes that someone less desperate might find and adopt the child before the cold or animals killed it. The belief that the Inuit regularly resorted to infanticide may be due in part to studies done by Asen Balikci,<ref>{{cite book |author=Balikci, Asen |title=The Netsilik Eskimo |publisher=Doubleday |location=Garden City, N.Y |year=1970 |isbn=0-385-05766-0 }}</ref> Milton Freeman,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Freeman, Milton M. R. |title=A Social and Ecologic Analysis of Systematic Female Infanticide among the Netsilik Eskimo |journal=American Anthropologist |volume=73 |issue=5 |pages=1011–8 |date=October 1971 |jstor=672815 |doi=10.1525/aa.1971.73.5.02a00020}}</ref> and David Riches<ref>{{cite journal |author=Riches, David. |title=The Netsilik Eskimo: A Special Case of Selective Female Infanticide |journal=Ethnology |volume=13 |issue=4 |pages=351–61 |date=October 1974 |jstor=3773051 |doi=10.2307/3773051}}</ref> among the [[Netsilik Inuit|Netsilik]], along with the trial of [[Kikkik]].<ref>[http://www.nunatsiaq.com/archives/nunavut020621/news/features/20621_1.html Remembering Kikkik]</ref><ref>[http://www.mysteriesofcanada.com/Nunavut/kikkik.htm Kikkik, When Justice Was Done]</ref> Children who could not be supported by a community due to a lack of resources were often killed as infants. This was seen as best for the culture and prevented the suffering of other family members.
===Other responsibilities === Along with childbirth and childcare, women were responsible for sewing skins to make clothes; preserving, processing, and cooking food (as mentioned above); caring for the sick and elderly; and helping to build and take care of the family's shelter.<ref name="Billson" /> Warm, light, and serviceable clothing was perhaps the greatest achievement of the Inuit. For protection against the bitter Arctic winter, it has not been surpassed by even the best modern clothing.<ref name="Morrison" />
The clothing created by women was vital because life in Arctic conditions was not possible without extremely well-made clothing to protect from the bitter cold. The clothing was created by the careful sewing of animal skins and furs using ivory needles, which were highly valuable in Inuit society. The process of preparing skins to be sewn together for creating clothes was done by women and was an arduous task. Skins had to be scraped, stretched, and softened before they were ready to be sewn.<ref name="Billson" />
In addition to this, the households Inuit women were expected to help construct and care for could range from [[igloo]]s, to semi-subterranean [[sod house]]s, to [[tent]]s in the summer months.<ref name="LeMoine" /> This required an understanding of complex architectural concepts, as well as the principles of insulation. A good amount of strength was required to construct Inuit shelters. Because of this, Inuit women often worked together and enlisted the help of men to build their homes. For both practical and social purposes, these houses would be built close together or were made large enough for more than one family to live in.<ref name="Friesen" />
==Status in Inuit culture== ===Sexual division of labour=== Jobs in Inuit culture were not considered men's work or [[women's work]], but the Inuit did believe in men's skills and women's skills. For example, hunting was generally done by the men. Sewing clothes, cooking and preparing food, gathering food outside of hunting, and caring for the home were generally done by women. This does not mean that women never hunted, nor that men never helped with other jobs. This was just how the work was traditionally divided.<ref name="LeMoine" />
Women hunted and boated for enjoyment or when food was scarce and the community needed extra hunters. Men and women worked together to create a functioning culture. The men would not be able to go hunting without the warm clothes the women sewed for them, and the women would not have enough food without the meat the men brought back from their hunting trips.<ref name="Billson" />
Because of this, the work done by women received equal respect to the work done by men. While men and women generally did different work, one type of work was not considered better or more important than other types. It is easy to think that because men only had one job that they did less work. The truth is that hunting was extremely physically demanding and time consuming, and often required traveling for days or weeks at a time. As a result, the [[Sexual Division of Labor (Evolutionary Perspective)|sexual division of labour]] in Inuit culture was relatively equal in the amount of work done.<ref name="Billson" />
===Lack of power and influence=== While women were respected by men, and often treated as equals, they did not have equal power in the community. Important decisions, such as when to [[Human migration|migrate]] and where to, could be made exclusively by men.<ref name="Billson" /> Inuit people had as [[Inuit#Traditional law|little government]] as any group on earth, but some groups did have tribal councils or groups of elders who made decisions for the community. These councils were almost exclusively male.<ref name="Morrison" />
Because of this, the Inuit women had little to no say in some of their communities' most important decisions. Men usually had the final say in issues such as arranging marriages and adoption or infanticide, which have a huge impact on women's lives. Although women had a relatively high position socially,<ref name="Morrison" /> and had significant control of their own home, as well as ceremonially important jobs such as lighting and tending to lamps and distributing food,<ref name="Labrador" /> their power was usually limited to those areas.
In addition to this, if men were unhappy with how a woman was handling her responsibilities, they could take over or transfer her work to another woman in the community whom they considered more capable. With women having less power, they are often put in difficult positions when they are not involved in the decision-making process. For example, a pregnant woman, or a woman with a newborn child, may not be able to migrate hundreds of miles through Arctic conditions in search of better hunting grounds. Factors such as these are rarely taken into account when men are the sole decision-makers for a community.<ref name="Billson" />
==Effects of modernization and change on Inuit women== [[File:Inuit Woman 1907 Crisco edit 2.jpg|thumb|An Inuit ([[Inupiat people|Inupiat]]) woman in traditional clothing, Nome, Alaska, 1907]] After contact with other cultures, the Inuit were introduced to new technologies and modernization, which changed their lives drastically. The Inuit are now a modern people and, like almost all indigenous peoples, no longer live the way their ancestors did. This is especially true of Inuit women.<ref name="Morrison" />
===New role in the culture=== After modernization, the Inuit began to move into Arctic towns and participate in [[Wage labour|wage labor]], government employment, community councils, and the acquisition of modern clothing, housing, and vehicles. Male Inuit initially took the lead in assimilation by learning the language of the arriving culture and taking on modern, wage earning jobs; however, a lack of education began to hinder the men's ability to find and keep jobs.<ref name="McElroy">McElroy, Ann. 1975. Canadian Arctic Modernization and Change in Female Inuit Role Identification. American Ethnologist 2(4): 662–686.</ref>
As a result of this, women began to lead the way in [[cultural assimilation]]. Women started by finding work as domestic servants, store clerks, hospital aides, classroom assistants, interpreters, and in weaving and knitting shops.<ref name="McElroy"/> Inuit women tend to go to school more than Inuit men, and this is especially true of college. Some universities in regions where the Inuit are prominent, such as the [[Nunavut Arctic College]], have programs designed specifically for the Inuit people. Women, much more often than men, take advantage of these programs.<ref name="Paskey">Paskey, Janice. 1999. Hunting for Seals and for Inuit Culture at Nunavut Arctic College. Chronicle of Higher Education 46(13): B4</ref>
Because Inuit women seek more education and, subsequently, better jobs, they have increasingly taken on the role as primary wage earner for the family. This has caused men to assume responsibilities in the house that were traditionally done by the women, such as raising children and keeping the home in order.<ref name="Billson" />
===Changes in status and power=== The "role reversal" that has begun to occur in Inuit society has given women a major increase in power and influence. Women have begun to seek more power for themselves, both in decision-making in the family and the culture as a whole. As the primary wage earners, working women are now considered the heads of their families and have the upper hand in making decisions for them. This has complicated the relationship between Inuit men and women. Men have begun to resent women for "stealing their rightful place as the head of the family"<ref name="Billson" /> and may turn to [[Alcoholism|drinking]] and/or [[Substance abuse|drug abuse]] to deal with these issues. However, this is not the only reason for men and women to start drinking/gambling/drugs, as you must remember that there has been extensive trauma endured from the 1960s scoop, and Residential schools. It can't all be blamed on woman taking power in a family system. There's lots of support for women to get employed from their family.
Reactions such as these perpetuate the cycle (and misinformation like this perpetuates the cycle), as men are less likely to be employed after exhibiting these behaviors. Another change that has begun is that Inuit women have increasingly started to run for political office. Although the positions they seek are often at the community and local levels, this increase in [[activism]] reflects the new confidence Inuit women have found in the modern world.<ref name="Billson" />
The second premier of [[Nunavut]] was a woman, [[Eva Aariak]], who was one of two female MLAs in the [[Legislative Assembly of Nunavut]]. The current mayor of [[Iqaluit]], the capital of Nunavut, is a woman, [[Elisapee Sheutiapik]], as is the Member of Parliament for Nunavut, [[Leona Aglukkaq]], who is also the Canadian [[Minister of Health (Canada)|Minister of Health]].
===Health issues=== Scientists have found that the Inuit people seem to experience more illness and health issues than other groups, especially the women and children, and especially in the post-modernization period.<ref name="Kent" /> A possible explanation is that the [[Inuit diet]] was traditionally high in fat and protein and low in fruits and vegetables.<ref name="Jorgensen">Jorgenson, Marit Eika with Helen Moustgaard, Peter Bjerregaard, and Knut Borch-Johnsen. 2006. Gender Differences in the Association between Westernization and Metabolic Risk Among Greenland Inuit. European Journal of Epidemiology 21(10): 741–748.</ref>
More likely explanations include a change in diet after modernization, a decrease in physical activity as traditional jobs such as hunting and constructing homes are practiced less and less, or exposure to alcohol, tobacco, and other drugs. Whatever the cause, [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], [[heart disease]], and [[Hypercholesterolemia|high cholesterol]] are serious problems for the Inuit people. Even more troubling, studies have shown that these issues are worse for women than other groups.<ref name="Jorgensen"/>
Another major issue facing the Inuit is that, after modernization, [[suicide]], [[Domestic violence|violence]], [[Major depressive disorder|depression]], and substance abuse have become increasingly prevalent. This may be the result of psychological issues stemming from not having a place in society or being torn between modern life and the culture of their ancestors. Sadly, suicide, depression, and substance abuse are increasingly becoming associated with Inuit women.
The pressure for Inuit women to conform to the dress and behavior of modern [[Western culture]] is immense; however, many aspects of modern culture are foreign to the Inuit women and are directly at odds with the traditional practices of their culture. Contemporary Inuit women are trapped between cultures, and the results are devastating to their physical and psychological health.<ref name="Billson" />
