{{for|the American football player|Jack Hoffman (American football)}} {{Infobox person | name = Jack Hoffman | image = President Barack Obama greets Jack Hoffman, April 29 2013 cropped.png | alt = | caption = Jack Hoffman in the Oval Office, April 29, 2013 | birth_name = Jack Hoffman | birth_date = {{birth date and age|2005|9|26}} | birth_place = [[Atkinson, Nebraska]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Student | awards = [[Best Moment ESPY Award|Best Moment ESPY Award 2013]] | known_for = Running for a touchdown for [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]] at age 7 with brain cancer | other_names = }} '''Jack Hoffman''' (born September 26, 2005) from [[Atkinson, Nebraska]], has [[Pediatrics|pediatric]] [[Brain tumor|brain cancer]]. In 2012, between his first and second brain surgeries, he was introduced to [[Rex Burkhead]], then a [[American football|football]] player for the [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football]] team. Subsequently, a close connection developed between Hoffman and the team. On April 6, 2013, at the annual Nebraska spring game, Hoffman at age 7 entered the game during the fourth quarter and ran for a {{convert|69|yd|m}} touchdown that received national and international attention. He subsequently met with President [[Barack Obama]], received a [[Best Moment ESPY Award]] for 2013, and the [[United States Senate]] approved a motion recognizing his role in raising awareness of pediatric brain cancer. The Team Jack Foundation was formed by his parents, Andy and Bri Hoffman, to raise money for pediatric brain research.
==Background== Hoffman was born and is growing up in Atkinson, Nebraska.<ref name =Litman/><ref name=Davis/> His parents are Andy and Bri Hoffman and he has two sisters, Ava and Reese.<ref name =Litman/><ref name=Davis/><ref name=AP1/>
On April 22, 2011 Hoffman was having breakfast with his parents when he became unresponsive. He was rushed to the local hospital in Atkinson, Nebraska, where he had a [[Tonic–clonic seizure|grand mal seizure]] lasting 30 minutes.<ref name =Litman> {{cite news|last=Litman|first=Laken|title=Little Jack Hoffman an inspiration to Nebraska football|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/gameon/2013/04/08/jack-hoffman-cancer-patient-nebraska-spring-game/2065451/|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=8 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcXaPnsE?url=http://www.usatoday.com/story/gameon/2013/04/08/jack-hoffman-cancer-patient-nebraska-spring-game/2065451/|archivedate=May 16, 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> He was then flown to [[Children's Hospital & Medical Center]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha]], [[Nebraska]], due to the life-threatening seizure.<ref name =Litman/><ref name=Ward> {{cite news|last=Ward|first=Andrew|title=Jack Hoffman, pediatric cancer patient, shares bond with NU running back Rex Burkhead|url=http://www.dailynebraskan.com/news/article_1b1db500-214e-11e2-b12b-001a4bcf6878.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[Daily Nebraskan]]|date=29 October 2012|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcjsDFoW?url=http://www.dailynebraskan.com/news/article_1b1db500-214e-11e2-b12b-001a4bcf6878.html|archivedate=16 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> He was subsequently diagnosed with a [[brain tumor]]. While at the hospital, Hoffman continued to have up to 10 to 12 seizures per day even though he was taking [[anticonvulsant]] medication. On May 20, 2011 he had surgery, but the [[neurosurgeon]] could only remove a small portion of the tumor.<ref name=Davis/> Subsequent pathology showed that it was a cancerous [[glioma]], [[Pediatrics|pediatric]] [[Brain tumor|brain cancer]]. Hoffman's parents then consulted [[Boston Children's Hospital]] for a second opinion. Neurosurgeon Liliana Goumnerova told the Hoffmans that she could remove the golf-ball sized tumor.<ref name =Litman/><ref name=Davis/><ref name=Ward/>
On October 10, 2011, Hoffman had a second surgery. Over 90% of the tumor was removed and the seizures stopped.<ref name =Litman/><ref name =York> {{cite news|last=York|first=Randy|title=Burkhead, Team Jack Members Smiling Everywhere|url=http://www.huskers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=205314182|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[University of Nebraska-Lincoln]]|date=10 October 2011}}</ref> Surgery was followed by another 60 weeks of chemotherapy.<ref name=Davis/><ref name=Kuruvilla>{{cite news|last=Kuruvilla|first=Carol|title=Young cancer patient who scored touchdown for Nebraska Huskers is beating the disease|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/8-year-old-brain-cancer-patient-scored-touchdown-nebraska-huskers-beating-disease-article-1.1480957|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=9 October 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcpICQzt?url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/8-year-old-brain-cancer-patient-scored-touchdown-nebraska-huskers-beating-disease-article-1.1480957|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Fox and Friends">{{cite news|last=[[Fox and Friends]]|title=After Memorable TD Run, 8-Year-Old Jack Hoffman Is Beating Cancer|url=http://foxnewsinsider.com/2013/10/17/interview-8-year-old-jack-hoffman-beating-brain-cancer-after-nebraska-touchdown-run|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[Fox News]]|date=17 October 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcprDPKG?url=http://foxnewsinsider.com/2013/10/17/interview-8-year-old-jack-hoffman-beating-brain-cancer-after-nebraska-touchdown-run|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> In October 2013, Hoffman's father reported that an MRI revealed that the remaining tumor was the same as in an MRI done in June, 2013, indicating that the cancerous tumor was not growing.<ref name=Lampe> {{cite news|last=Lampe|first=Nelson|title=Cancer in Remission for Neb. Boy who Made TD Run|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/young-neb-boy-who-made-td-run-remission|accessdate=17 May 2014|agency=Associated Press|date=7 October 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcwGXDFJ?url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/young-neb-boy-who-made-td-run-remission|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> As of April 2014, his cancer was still in remission.<ref name=Healey/><ref name=Dunker> {{cite news|last=Dunker|first=Chris|title=A year after 'The Run,' Jack Hoffman not interested in spotlight|url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/a-year-after-the-run-jack-hoffman-not-interested-in/article_42f74de7-b4d6-5893-a9c4-2ec06227348b.html|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[Lincoln Journal Star]]|date=11 April 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PclAbbaR?url=http://journalstar.com/news/local/a-year-after-the-run-jack-hoffman-not-interested-in/article_42f74de7-b4d6-5893-a9c4-2ec06227348b.html|archivedate=16 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Touchdown run== During the time between Hoffman's first and second surgeries, his father called Keith Zimmer who was the associate director of [[Life Skills]] at the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln]] [[Nebraska Cornhuskers|Athletic Department]].<ref name=Ward/> He wanted to get a picture of his son with his favorite Nebraska [[American football|football]] player, [[Rex Burkhead]].<ref name=Ward/> Burkhead agreed and met the family in September 2011. He had lunch with the Hoffman family, showed them [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], and decided he wanted to keep in touch with Hoffman.<ref name=Ward/> On Friday, October 7, 2011, Burkead called Hoffman before his second surgery to wish him well.<ref name=Ward/> The next day Nebraska played [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] in a game nationally televised by [[ESPN College Football|ABC]], and ABC announcers mentioned Hoffman's story.<ref name=Ward/><ref name =York/> At halftime of the game, Nebraska trailed Ohio State 20-6.<ref name =Litman/> At that time Burkhead thought about Hoffman and he said to his teammates "Jack's not giving up and we're not giving up." Nebraska ended up winning the game, 34-27, which was the largest comeback in Nebraska football history.<ref name =Litman/>
In September 2012, Hoffman walked with the Nebraska players on to the field for their game against [[Wisconsin Badgers football|Wisconsin]].<ref name=Davis/> In April 2013, as the spring football game neared, Jeff Jamrog (Assistant Athletic Director for Football) had the idea of getting Hoffman into the spring game.<ref name=Davis/> He ran the idea by football coach [[Bo Pelini]] the night before the game and Pelini approved.<ref name="Fox and Friends"/> Jamrog told the Hoffmans about their plan to get Jack into the game that night and the Hoffmans quickly made a uniform for him to wear the next day.<ref name=Davis/><ref name="Fox and Friends"/>
During the game, the Hoffmans were on the sidelines with the team.<ref name=Davis/> As the fourth quarter began, the Red team had fourth down and one yard to go on their own 32 yard line. Pelini called timeout and sent Hoffman into the game wearing number 22 (Rex Burkhead's number). As the play began, Nebraska [[quarterback]] [[Taylor Martinez]] initially guided Hoffman in the right direction and then he ran {{convert|69|yd|m}} for a touchdown.<ref name=Davis/> When he reached the end zone, the players lifted him onto their shoulders in front of 60,174 people at Memorial Stadium.<ref name=Davis/>
The story leading up to the touchdown run and the video of the run were covered extensively nationally<ref name =Litman/><ref name=Davis/><ref>{{cite news|title=Special moment in spring scrimmage|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/9142300/jack-hoffman-7-scores-nebraska-cornhuskers-spring-game|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[ESPN]]|date=7 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdAXEP4B?url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/9142300/jack-hoffman-7-scores-nebraska-cornhuskers-spring-game|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=Boren>{{cite news|last=Boren|first=Cindy|title=7-year-old cancer patient scores in Nebraska spring game (video)|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2013/04/07/7-year-old-cancer-patient-scores-in-nebraska-spring-game-video/|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=7 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdAoF3RV?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/early-lead/wp/2013/04/07/7-year-old-cancer-patient-scores-in-nebraska-spring-game-video/|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Jack Hoffman Touchdown: 7-Year-Old Brain Cancer Patient Scores In Nebraska Spring Game (VIDEO)|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/07/jack-hoffman-touchdown-nebraska-spring-cancer_n_3033583.html|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[Huffington Post]]|date=7 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdB3AUxQ?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/07/jack-hoffman-touchdown-nebraska-spring-cancer_n_3033583.html|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> and internationally.<ref name=Guardian>{{cite news|title=Cancer patient Jack Hoffman, 7, scores touchdown for Nebraska – video|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/video/2013/apr/08/jack-hoffman-scores-touchdown-nebraska-video|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=8 April 2013}}</ref> By April 16, 2013, a [[YouTube]] video of the touchdown run had been viewed over seven million times.<ref name=Huston/>
==Team Jack== After Rex Burkhead met Hoffman, a bond began to grow between him and the Nebraska football team.<ref name=Davis/> The players decided to start an initiative to raise money for cancer research they called "Team Jack."<ref name=Davis/> Team Jack sold 30,000 T-shirts and collected $275,000 in donations, which they gave to the [[Dana Farber Cancer Institute]] in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]. The Hoffman family subsequently established the Team Jack Foundation,<ref name=Dunker/> which has raised almost $1.5 million for pediatric brain cancer research.<ref name=Healey/>
==Awards, celebrity, and influence== [[File:President Barack Obama greets Jack Hoffman, April 29 2013.jpg|thumb|President Barack Obama greets Jack Hoffman, April 29 2013 in the Oval Office]] On April 29, 2013, the Hoffman family and Rex Burkhead met with President Barack Obama in the [[Oval Office]] for 15 minutes. Obama told Hoffman that he was proud of him and gave him a football. When asked about his meeting with the president, Hoffman replied "I thought it was awesome."<ref name=AP1> {{cite news|agency=Associated Press|title=Obama meets Jack Hoffman, young cancer patient who won hearts in Nebraska football game|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/obama-meets-jack-hoffman-young-cancer-patient-who-won-hearts-in-nebraska-football-game/|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|date=30 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcXtuhDh?url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/obama-meets-jack-hoffman-young-cancer-patient-who-won-hearts-in-nebraska-football-game/|archivedate=16 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
In May, 2013, [[Upper Deck Company]] made a "Star Rookie" trading card for Hoffman. Upper Deck's sports marketing manager explained why they created the trading card: "Jack is the type of inspirational athlete who absolutely deserves an Upper Deck rookie card."<ref name=Huston>{{cite news|last=Huston|first=Chris|title=Seven-year-old Nebraska running back sensation gets a trading card|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/eye-on-college-football/22084340/seven-year-old-nebraska-running-back-sensation-gets-a-trading-card|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[CBS Sports]]|date=16 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcnG5RkP?url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/eye-on-college-football/22084340/seven-year-old-nebraska-running-back-sensation-gets-a-trading-card|archivedate=16 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> The sale of the cards has brought in $50,000 for the Team Jack Foundation.<ref name=Sarasota>{{cite news|title=Running for touchdown, and for his life|url=http://extra.heraldtribune.com/2014/05/18/running-touchdown-life/|accessdate=19 May 2014|newspaper=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]|date=18 May 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PgAV01JT?url=http://extra.heraldtribune.com/2014/05/18/running-touchdown-life/|archivedate=19 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> After attending the May 16, 2014, 19th Annual [[Dick Vitale]] Gala,<ref name=Johnston>{{cite news|last=Johnston|first=Joey|title=Vitale devoted to raising funds for cancer research|url=http://tbo.com/sports/colleges/vitale-devoted-to-raising-funds-for-cancer-research-20140514/|accessdate=19 May 2014|newspaper=[[The Tampa Tribune]]|date=14 May 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PgCmak9m?url=http://tbo.com/sports/colleges/vitale-devoted-to-raising-funds-for-cancer-research-20140514/|archivedate=19 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> where Hoffman signed a trading card for Dick Vitale, the ''[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]]'' wrote: "Yes, he may be an 8-year-old celebrity, but really, he’d much rather be a regular kid."<ref name=Sarasota/>
Hoffman won an [[ESPY Award]] for [[Best Moment ESPY Award]] in 2013.<ref name=Davis> {{cite news|last=Davis|first=Seth|title=My Sportsman: Nebraska fan Jack Hoffman|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/sportsman/news/20131211/jack-hoffman-my-sportsman/|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=11 December 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcWGc9m4?url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/sportsman/news/20131211/jack-hoffman-my-sportsman/|archivedate=16 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name=Healey> {{cite news|last=Healey|first=Katy|title=One year later, Jack Hoffman's touchdown run still resonates|url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20140411/LIVEWELL/140419586/1161|accessdate=16 May 2014|newspaper=[[Omaha World-Herald]]|date=12 April 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PcWwaBA0?url=http://www.omaha.com/article/20140411/LIVEWELL/140419586/1161|archivedate=16 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref> {{cite news|last=Rittenberg|first=Adam|title=Jack Hoffman wins ESPY for best moment|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/bigten/post/_/id/79842/jack-hoffman-wins-espy-for-best-moment|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[ESPN]]|date=18 July 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdpNVK4z?url=http://espn.go.com/blog/bigten/post/_/id/79842/jack-hoffman-wins-espy-for-best-moment|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> Hoffman's touchdown run was listed fifth in The Best Emotional Moment in sports for 2013 by ''[[USA Today]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lepore|first=Steve|title=The Best Emotional Moment of 2013|url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/year-in-sports/2013/11/25/ad-meter-category-best-emotional-moment/3283005/|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=18 December 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdoMIlms?url=http://admeter.usatoday.com/story/sports/ad-meter/year-in-sports/2013/11/25/ad-meter-category-best-emotional-moment/3283005/|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> Hoffman was also one of five nominees for [[Sportsman of the Year]] by ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' in 2013.<ref name=Davis/><ref>{{cite news|title=2013 Sportsman of the Year|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/magazine/sportsman/|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[Sports Illustrated]]|date=2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Pe7tl1Ap?url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/magazine/sportsman/|archivedate=May 17, 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
Senator [[Deb Fischer]] offered a resolution to the Senate that states that pediatric brain cancer is a leading cause of death. The resolution also singles out Hoffman's touchdown run for increasing awareness of pediatric brain cancer: {{quote|Whereas on April 6, 2013, 7-year-old pediatric brain cancer patient Jack Hoffman joined the lineup of the University of Nebraska Cornhuskers football team for its spring football game, wearing football pads and a number 22 jersey, and ran 69 yards to score a touchdown in front of more than 60,000 fans at Memorial Stadium in Lincoln, Nebraska, touching the hearts of millions of Americans and raising awareness of pediatric brain cancer.<ref name=Morton>{{cite news|last=Morton|first=Joseph|title=U.S. Senate honors Husker spring game star Jack Hoffman|url=http://omaha.com/article/20130425/NEWS/130429770/1685|accessdate=17 May 2014|newspaper=[[Omaha World-Herald]]|date=25 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PdrC2zsu?url=http://omaha.com/article/20130425/NEWS/130429770/1685|archivedate=17 May 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> }}
==Cancer returns== On August 5, 2014, Hoffman found out that his tumor had grown since his April, 2014 MRI. His father reported that in April, there was a spot in his scan, but that they had hoped that it was nothing. Hoffman will likely undergo further chemotherapy or surgery.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Riley|title=Jack Hoffman's fight against cancer dealt a setback, father says|url=http://journalstar.com/sports/huskers/football/jack-hoffman-s-fight-against-cancer-dealt-a-setback-father/article_6ce73ae7-80e5-5f8b-94cb-1e150a4e57fa.html|accessdate=8 August 2014|newspaper=[[Lincoln Journal Star]]|date=6 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sherman|first1=Mitch|title=Cancer returns for Jack Hoffman|url=http://espn.go.com/college-football/story/_/id/11318988/brain-cancer-returns-jack-hoffman|accessdate=8 August 2014|publisher=''[[ESPN]]''|date=6 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Litman|first1=Laken|title=8-year-old Nebraska superfan Jack Hoffman learns his cancer has returned|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/08/8-year-old-nebraska-superfan-jack-hoffman-cancer-returned|accessdate=8 August 2014|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|date=8 August 2014}}</ref> After consultation with Hoffman's medical team, in mid-August 2014, his parents decided to pursue a clinical trial in Boston involving a genetic therapy approach in part because the cancer has spread to the brain stem making surgery difficult.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jack Hoffman's heading to Boston to continue fight with cancer|url=http://www.ketv.com/news/jack-hoffmans-heading-to-boston-to-continue-fight-with-cancer/27565758#!bFppkK|accessdate=18 August 2014|publisher=[[KETV]]|date=17 August 2014|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RuUYOTKu?url=http://www.ketv.com/news/jack-hoffmans-heading-to-boston-to-continue-fight-with-cancer/27565758|archivedate=18 August 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Team Jack announces treatment decision|url=http://www.klkntv.com/story/26301128/team-jack-announces-treatment-decision|accessdate=18 August 2014|publisher=[[KLKN]]|date=17 August 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819082628/http://www.klkntv.com/story/26301128/team-jack-announces-treatment-decision|archivedate=19 August 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | pre-nominals = [[The Reverend]] | name = Jon Sobrino | post-nominals = [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] | image = Jon Sobrino - 2013.jpg | alt = | caption = Sobrino in 2013 | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1938|12|27|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Barcelona]], Spain | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | residence = [[El Salvador]] | nationality = | home_town = | module = {{Infobox clergy |child=yes | religion = Christianity ([[Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]]) | church = [[Latin Church]] | ordained = }} | module2 = {{Infobox academic |child=yes | alma_mater = {{unbulleted list | [[Saint Louis University]] | Hochschule Sankt Georgen, [[Frankfurt]]}} | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | school_tradition = [[Liberation theology]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | influences = {{hlist | [[Ignacio Ellacuría]] | [[Karl Marx]]<ref>{{cite thesis |last=Erichsen |first=Ola Bakken |year=2013 |title=Jon Sobrinos korsteologiske konstruksjon : Hvordan og hvorfor konstruerer Jon Sobrino sin korsteologi? |degree=master's |language=no |location=Oslo, Norway |publisher=University of Oslo |page=13 |hdl=10852/37106 |hdl-access=free}}</ref> | [[Jürgen Moltmann]] | [[Karl Rahner]]}} | era = | discipline = [[Theology]] | sub_discipline = [[Christology]] | workplaces = [[Central American University]] | doctoral_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | notable_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | main_interests = | notable_works = {{unbulleted list | ''Jesus the Liberator'' (1991) | ''Christ the Liberator'' (1999)}} | notable_ideas = | influenced = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> }} | signature = | signature_alt = }} '''Jon Sobrino''' {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Society of Jesus|SJ]]}} (born 1938) is a [[Jesuit]] [[Catholic]] priest and [[theology|theologian]], known mostly for his contributions to [[liberation theology]]. He received worldwide attention in 2007 when the Vatican's [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith]] issued a [[notification (Holy See)|notification]] for what they termed doctrines that are "erroneous or dangerous and may cause harm to the faithful."
==Life== Born 27 December 1938 into a [[Basque people|Basque]] family in Barcelona, Sobrino entered the [[Society of Jesus]] when he was 18. The following year, in 1958, he was sent to [[El Salvador]]. He later studied engineering at [[Saint Louis University]], an American Jesuit university, and then theology at [[Sankt Georgen Graduate School of Philosophy and Theology]] in [[Frankfurt]] in [[West Germany]] for his Doctor of Theology (Dr.theol.) degree. Returning to [[El Salvador]], he taught at the Jesuit-run [[Universidad Centroamericana "José Simeón Cañas"|University of Central America (UCA)]] in [[San Salvador]], which he helped to found.
On 16 November 1989 he narrowly escaped the [[Murder of UCA scholars|murder of the UCA scholars]] by the Atlacatl Battalion, an elite unit of the Salvadoran Army. By a coincidence, he was away from El Salvador when members of the military broke into the rectory at the UCA and brutally murdered his six fellow Jesuits, [[Ignacio Ellacuría]], [[Segundo Montes]], Juan Ramón Moreno, [[Ignacio Martín-Baró]], Amando López, and Joaquín López y López, and their housekeeper Elba Ramos and her 16-year-old daughter Celina Ramos. The Jesuits were targeted for their outspoken work to bring a resolution to the brutal [[El Salvador Civil War]] that left about 75,000 men, women, and children dead, mostly civilians.
Investigated by the Vatican throughout his career as a professor of theology, he has remained an outspoken proponent of peace, joining protests in 2008 of the continued training of Latin American military officers in torture techniques at the [[School of the Americas]] at [[Fort Benning]].<ref name=":0">{{cite web | author = John Dear | url=http://ncronline.org/blogs/road-peace/jon-sobrino-soa-protest | title =With Jon Sobrino at the SOA Protest | work =NCROnline | accessdate =25 November 2008}}</ref>
==Works==
Sobrino's main works are ''Jesus the Liberator'' (1991) and its sequel ''Christ the Liberator'' (1999), along with ''[[Christology]] at the Crossroads'' (1978), ''The True Church and the Poor'' (1984), ''Spirituality of Liberation'' (1990), ''The Principle of Mercy: Taking the Crucified People from the Cross'' (Orbis, 1994), ''No Salvation Outside the Poor'', and ''Prophetic-Utopian Essays'' (Orbis, 2008).<ref name=":0" />
==Vatican notification==
Because of the theological positions he took in his works, Sobrino was the subject of a theological [[notification (Holy See)|notification]]; a critique statement and an admonishment by the [[Holy See|Vatican]] and the [[Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith]] in March 2007.
The congregation declared that Sobrino placed too great an emphasis on the human nature of [[Jesus Christ]], downplaying Jesus' divine nature, and that his "works contain propositions which are either erroneous or dangerous and may cause harm to the faithful."
While certain of his teachings were declared false, the congregation did not condemn or censure him, or prohibit him from teaching or lecturing. However, [[Federico Lombardi]] at the [[Vatican Press Office]] hinted at the possibility that his bishop or superior in the Jesuit order might choose to take action.<ref name=":1">[http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20070318010724/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/0701439.htm Vatican Criticizes Jesuit Liberation Theologian, Issues No Sanctions] Catholic News Service, 15 March 2007</ref>
The congregation emphasized in the notification that it was issued as part of its service "to the people of God, and particularly to the simple and poorest members of the Church." They emphasized the people's "right to know the truth ... about Christ" and therefore their corresponding duty to intervene. The notification was premised on Benedict XVI's teaching that "the first poverty among people is not to know Christ."
According to the Notification, Sobrino's erroneous propositions concerned: "1) the methodological presuppositions on which the Author bases his theological reflection, 2) the Divinity of Jesus Christ, 3) the Incarnation of the Son of God, 4) the relationship between Jesus Christ and the Kingdom of God, 5) the Self-consciousness of Jesus, and 6) the salvific value of his Death."<ref name=":1" />
At the root of what the Vatican saw as Sobrino's error is his affirmation that "the '[[Church of the poor]]' is the ecclesial 'setting' of Christology and offers it its fundamental orientation." However, the Vatican believes that it is "only the [[apostolic faith]] which the Church has transmitted through all generations that constitutes the ecclesial setting of Christology and of theology in general."<ref name=":1" />
Contrary to criticisms that the Vatican acted without due consultation and unfairly, the Vatican says that a Notification is made after notifying the author of the statements that are seen to be problematic and after awaiting a reply from the author who is given 3 months whereby to respond.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927194442/http://212.77.1.245/news_services/bulletin/news/19857.php?index=19857&lang=po#TRADUZIONE%20IN%20LINGUA%20%20INGLESE Holy See - Vatican City State]</ref>
Retired professor of theology Peter Hünermann (then Tübingen, Germany)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fsspx.news/en/news-events/news/liberation-theologian-barred-teaching-and-publishing-21575|title=Liberation Theologian Barred from Teaching and Publishings|website=fsspx.news|language=en|access-date=16 December 2017}}</ref> declared in April 2007 that the Vatican notification was a "shock" for all theologians, because along with Sobrino "the most distinguished exegetes and systematic theologians – both Catholic and Protestant – stood in the dock".<ref>{{cite journal |first=Peter |last=Hünermann |url=http://www.khg-oldenburg.de/index.php?option=com_docman&task=doc_download&gid=32&Itemid=42 |title=Moderne Qualitätssicherung? Der Fall Jon Sobrino ist eine Anfrage an die Arbeit der Glaubenskongregation |journal=Herder-Korrespondenz |volume=61 |date=2007 |issue=4 |pages=184-188 |language=German }}</ref> Supported by more than 100 professors of Catholic theology, Hünermann also demanded an "intelligent redevelopment" of the Vatican Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, because, as successor organization of the Holy Office, it still had the structure of an "early modern board of censors".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://cathnews.com/cathnews/12982-theologians-back-call-for-cdf-quotrestructuring-quot|title=Theologians Back Call for CDF "Restructuring"|website=cathnews.com|language=en-gb|access-date=16 December 2017}}</ref>
Sobrino's work was reviewed by a number of theologians, including {{ill|Bernard Sesboüé|fr}}, {{ill|José Ignacio González Faus|es}}, [[Javier Vitoria]], Carlo Palacio of [[Bello Horizonte]], and Martin Maier, editor of the German Jesuit periodical ''[[Stimmen der Zeit]]''. These theologians found no doctrinal errors in Sobrino's works. It is not apparent that their findings have been considered by the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith.<ref name="Pope 2015 p. 237">{{cite book | last=Pope | first=Stephen J. | title=Hope and Solidarity: Jon Sobrino's Challenge to Christian Theology | publisher=Orbis Books | year=2015 | isbn=978-1-60833-276-2 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0CnOBgAAQBAJ&pg=PT237 | page=237}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Allen |first=John L., Jr. |title=Vatican Censures Sobrino, Who Calls Procedures 'Not Honest' | work=National Catholic Reporter | date=14 March 2007 | url=https://www.ncronline.org/news/vatican-censures-sobrino-who-calls-procedures-not-honest}}</ref>

{{good article}} {{Infobox royalty |consort = yes | name = Julia Domna | title = Empress consort of the Roman Empire | image = Giulia domna, moglie di settimio severo, con busto non pertinente, inv. 2210.JPG | caption = Bust of Julia Domna, [[Vatican Museums]] |succession = [[Empress consort]] of the [[Roman Empire]] |reign = 193 AD - 211 AD | full name = Julia Domna | spouse = [[Septimius Severus]] | issue = {{plainlist| * [[Caracalla]] * [[Geta (emperor)|Geta]] }} | dynasty = [[Severan dynasty|Severan]] | father = [[Julius Bassianus]] | mother = | birth_date = c. 160 AD | birth_place = [[Emesa]], [[Syria (Roman province)|Syria]] | death_date = 217 AD (aged 57) | death_place = [[Rome]], [[Italy]] | date of burial = | place of burial = [[Mausoleum of Hadrian]] |}} {{Severan dynasty |image={{multiple image|align=center|total_width=200|image_style=border:none |image1=Julia_Maesa_antoninianus_2.png |caption1=[[Antoninianus]] of Julia Maesa |image2=Julia-domna.jpg |caption2=Coin featuring Julia Domna }} }} '''Julia Domna''' (AD 160–217) was a Roman empress of [[Roman Syria|Syrian]] origins, the second wife of [[Septimius Severus]] (reigned 193–211). She was born in [[Emesa]] in the Roman province of Syria, into a family of priests of the deity [[Elagabalus (deity)|Elagabalus]].
As a powerful political figure and member of the imperial family, Julia received titles such as "mother of the army camps". She was famous for her political influence.
After Severus' death in 211, his two sons with Julia, [[Publius Septimius Geta|Geta]] and [[Caracalla]], ruled jointly over Rome. Caracalla had Geta assassinated later that year. Julia continued to have a powerful role during the reign of Caracalla. Julia is thought to have committed suicide in 217 upon hearing of the assassination of Caracalla. After her death, her older sister [[Julia Maesa]] successfully contended for political power.
== Family background == Julia Domna was born in [[Emesa]] (modern day [[Homs]]) in Syria around 160 AD<ref>Burns, Jasper (2006). [https://books.google.com/books/about/Great_Women_of_Imperial_Rome.html?id=EWy3AwAAQBAJ&source=kp_book_description ''Great Women of Imperial Rome: Mothers and Wives of the Caesars'']. Routledge. {{ISBN|978-1-134-13184-6}}: "The date of Julia's birth is not known, but coins of her sister Julia Maesa, minted about 220, show a woman nearing 60 (see figures 11.2, 11.17). Thus Julia Domna was probably born around 160."</ref> to a family of Arab descent.<ref> *{{cite book |last1=Gagarin |first1=Michael |title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of Ancient Greece and Rome |date=2010 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-1951-7072-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lNV6-HsUppsC&pg=RA3-PA141 |page=3}} *{{cite book|author1=Bowman, Alan|author2=Garnsey, Peter|author3=Cameron, Averil|title=The Cambridge Ancient History: Volume 12, The Crisis of Empire, AD 193-337|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MNSyT_PuYVMC&pg=PA502|date=September 8, 2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-30199-2|page=502}} *{{cite book|author=Ball, Warwick|title=Rome in the East: The Transformation of an Empire|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=07pTDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT769|date=June 10, 2016|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-317-29634-8|page=769}}</ref><ref> *{{cite book|author=Bowersock, Glen Warren|title=Roman Arabia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L4NBigJ3NF4C&pg=PA128|year=1994|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-77756-9|page=128}} *{{cite book |title=Rome and the Arabs : A Prolegomenon to the Study of Byzantium and the Arabs|author=Shahîd, Irfan|authorlink1=Irfan Shahîd|date=1984|page=167 |publisher=Dumbarton Oaks Research Library and Collection |isbn=0-88402-115-7}} *{{cite book |last1=Bowersock |first1=Glen Warren |title=Roman Arabia |date=1994 |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=978-0-6747-7756-9 |pages=126-128 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=L4NBigJ3NF4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0674777565#PPA126,M1}} *{{cite book |last1=Rodinson |first1=Maxime |authorlink1=Maxime Rodinson |title=The Arabs |date=1981 |publisher=University of Chicago Press |isbn=978-0-2267-2356-3 |page=55 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RJ0PWha-o8wC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn:0226723569#PPA55,M1}}</ref> Her name, Domna, is an archaic Arabic word that means black. She was the youngest daughter of the high-priest of Ba'al [[Julius Bassianus|Gaius Julius Bassianus]] and sister to [[Julia Maesa]]. Through her sister and Maesa's husband [[Julius Avitus]], Julia Domna had two nieces: [[Julia Soaemias]] and [[Julia Mamaea]], the respective mothers of future Roman emperors [[Elagabalus]] and [[Severus Alexander]].<ref name="Levick2007">{{cite book|author=Levick, Barbara|title=Julia Domna: Syrian Empress|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BjkfKsCttrkC&pg=PA18|date=10 May 2007|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-32351-7|pages=18}}</ref>
Julia's ancestors were [[Royal family of Emesa|priest kings]] of the famous temple of [[Elagabalus (deity)|Elagabalus]]. The family had enormous wealth and was promoted to Roman senatorial aristocracy. Before her marriage, Julia inherited the estate of her paternal great-uncle [[Julius Agrippa]], a former leading [[centurion]].<ref name="Levick2007"/>
=== Marriage === In the late 180s, Julia married the Libyan Roman general [[Septimius Severus]]. The marriage proved happy, and Severus cherished Julia and her political opinions, since she was very well-read and a student of philosophy. They had two sons, Caracalla ([[Caracalla|Lucius Septimius Bassianus]]) in 188 and Geta ([[Publius Septimius Geta]]) in 189.<ref>Birley, Anthony (1999). ''Septimius Severus: The African Emperor'', Routledge, p. 76-77. {{ISBN|0-203-02859-7}}.</ref>
== Civil war== {{Main article|Year of the Five Emperors}} After the Roman emperor [[Commodus]] was murdered without an heir in 192, many contenders rushed for the throne, including Julia's husband, Septimius Severus. An elder senator, [[Pertinax]], was appointed by the praetorian guard as the new emperor of Rome. But when Pertinax would not meet the guard's demands, he too was murdered.<ref name="Rahman">{{cite book | url=https://thecorner.wordpress.com/2006/06/05/the-african-emperor-the-life-career-and-rise-to-power-of-septimius-severus/ | title=The African Emperor? The Life, Career, and Rise to Power of Septimius Severus, MA thesis | publisher=[[University of Wales Lampeter]] | author=Rahman, Abdur | year=2001}}</ref> Another politician, [[Didius Julianus]], was called to Rome and appointed emperor. Severus, coming from the north into Rome, overthrew Julianus and had him executed. Severus claimed the title of emperor in 193. By offering [[Clodius Albinus]], a powerful governor of [[Britannia]], the rank of [[Caesar (title)|Caesar]] (successor), Severus could focus on his other rival to the throne, [[Pescennius Niger]], whom he defeated at the [[Battle of Issus (194)|Battle of Issus]] in 194.<ref>Birley, Anthony (1999). ''Septimius Severus: The African Emperor'', Routledge, p. 89-128. {{ISBN|0-203-02859-7}}.</ref> When afterwards Severus declared openly his son Caracalla as successor, Clodius Albinus was hailed emperor by his troops. At the [[Battle of Lugdunum]] in 197, Severus defeated and killed Albinus, establishing himself as Emperor. Thus Julia Domna became Empress consort.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/36750306|title=Roman Britain and the English settlements|last=1889–1943.|first=Collingwood, R. G. (Robin George),|date=1998|origyear=1936|publisher=Biblo and Tannen|others=Myres, J. N. L. (John Nowell Linton)|isbn=0819611603|location=[New York, N.Y.]|oclc=36750306}}</ref>
=== Power and influence === Unlike most imperial wives, Julia remarkably accompanied her husband on his military campaigns and stayed in camp with the army.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|title=Julia Domna 170 CE Syria |url=http://www.women-philosophers.com/Julia-Domna.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120530033857/http://www.women-philosophers.com/Julia-Domna.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 May 2012 |website=Women-philosophers |accessdate=6 March 2014 |df= }}</ref> During this time, honorary titles were granted to Julia similar to those given to [[Faustina the Younger]], including ''mater castorum'', mother of the camp,<ref name="levick">{{Cite book|title=Julia Domna: Syrian Empress|last=Levick|first=Barbara|publisher=Routledge|year=2007|isbn=9781134323517|location=|page=66}}</ref> ''mater Augustus'', mother of Augustus, and ''mater patriae, mother of the fatherland.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bernario|first=H. W.|year=1958|title=Julia Domna: Mater Senatus et Patriae|url=|journal=Phoenix|volume=12|pages=67–70|via=}}</ref>
The empress was involved in building projects, most notably the ''[[Temple of Vesta|aedes Vestae]]'' after the fire of Commodus in 192 destroyed areas of the temple and the home, or Atrium, of the Vestal Virgins; based on numismatic evidence, historical authors, and a laconic inscription found ''in situ'', some scholars agree that Julia funded restorations to the site during Septimius Severus's reign.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Portraits of the Vestal Virgins: Priestesses of Ancient Rome|last=Lindner|first=M. M.|publisher=University of Michigan Press|year=2015|isbn=|location=Ann Arbor, MI|pages=}}</ref>
Julia was respected and viewed positively for most of her tenure, as indicators and evidence include the coins minted with her portrait, mentioning her with several honorary titles and also simply as "Julia Augusta". Julia is said to have exceeded all other Roman empresses in titles and honours.<ref name=levick /> The hairstyle that she used would later be worn by Roman empress [[Cornelia Salonina]] and [[Palmyra]]n queen [[Zenobia]].<ref name="Southern2008">{{cite book|author=Southern, Pat|title=Empress Zenobia: Palmyra's Rebel Queen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DqMrR29Cc7MC|date=2 August 2018|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-441-17351-5|pages=119}}</ref>
== Transition of power == When Severus died in 211 in [[Eboracum]] ([[York]]), Julia became the mediator between their two sons, Caracalla and Geta, who were supposed to rule as joint emperors, according to their father's wishes expressed in his will. The two young men were never fond of each other and quarrelled frequently. Geta was murdered by Caracalla's soldiers in the same year.<ref>{{Cite book|title=How Rome Fell: death of a superpower|last=Goldsworthy|first=Adrian|publisher=New Haven: Yale University Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-300-16426-8|pages=68–69}}</ref> Geta's name was then removed from inscriptions and [[Damnatio memoriae|his image was erased]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ancient Rome|last=Dunstan|first=William E.|publisher=Lanham: Rowman and Littlefield|year=2011|isbn=978-0-7425-6832-7|pages=405–406}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=How Rome Fell: death of a superpower|last=Goldsworthy|first=Adrian|publisher=New Haven: Yale University Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-300-16426-8|pages=70–71}}</ref>
=== Death === During his campaign against the [[Parthian empire]] in 217, Caracalla was assassinated by a soldier.<ref>{{Cite book|title=How Rome Fell: death of a superpower|last=Goldsworthy|first=Adrian|publisher=New Haven: Yale University Press|year=2009|isbn=978-0-300-16426-8|location=|pages=74}}</ref> Julia chose to commit suicide after hearing about the rebellion,<ref name="CJones" /><ref>Birley, Anthony (1999). ''Septimius Severus: The African Emperor'', Routledge, p. 192. {{ISBN|0-203-02859-7}}.</ref> perhaps a decision hastened by the fact that she was suffering from [[breast cancer]], as well as a reluctance to return to private life.<ref>Potter, David S (2004). ''The Roman Empire at Bay AD 180–395'', Routledge, p. 148. {{ISBN|0-415-10058-5}}.</ref> Her sister Julia Maesa restored the Severan dynasty about a year after Julia Domna's death.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HF0m3spOebcC|title=Encyclopedia of Women in the Ancient World|first=Joyce E.|last=Salisbury|year=2001|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781576070925|pages=183}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hL99AgAAQBAJ|title=Great Women of Imperial Rome: Mothers and Wives of the Caesars|last=Burns|first=Jasper|publisher=Routledge|year=2006|isbn=9781134131853|pages=209}}</ref> Julia Domna's body was brought to Rome and placed in the ''Sepulcrum C. et L. Caesaris'' (perhaps a separate chamber in the [[Mausoleum of Augustus]]). Later, however, both her bones and those of Geta were transferred by Julia Maesa to the [[Mausoleum of Hadrian]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Cassius Dio — Epitome of Book 79 |url=http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/79*.html#78-24.4 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120526042142/http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Cassius_Dio/79*.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-05-26 |website=University of Chicago}}</ref>
== Legacy == Julia Domna is remembered for encouraging [[Philostratus]] to write ''[[Life of Apollonius of Tyana]]''.<ref name="Dzielska">{{cite book| title = Apollonius of Tyana in Legend and History| edition = | last1 = Dzielska| first1 = Maria |author1-link=Maria Dzielska| last2 = Stucchi | first2 = Sandro| year = 1986| publisher = | isbn = 88-7062-599-0| pages = 14}}</ref> Julia is thought to have died before Philostratus could finish his work of eight volumes.<ref name="CJones">{{cite book| title = Philostratus, The Life of Apollonius of Tyana| edition = | last = Jones| first = Christopher P. | year = 2005| publisher = Harvard University Press| id = | pages = 2}}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Kathryn Johanna Kuhlman Kathryn Kuhlman.jpeg | caption = Kathryn Kuhlman | birth_date = {{birth date|1907|5|9|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Johnson County, Missouri]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|1976|2|20|1907|5|9|mf=y}} | death_place = [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], U.S. | nationality = American (of German ancestry) | occupation = [[Evangelism|Evangelist]] | known_for = Miraculous healings | spouse = Burroughs Allen Waltrip ("Mister"), October 18, 1938– ? 1948 (divorced) }}
'''Kathryn Kuhlman''' (May 9, 1907 – February 20, 1976) was an American [[Pentecostal]] [[Evangelism|evangelist]] known for hosting healing services.
==Personal life== Kathryn Johanna Kuhlman was born in [[Concordia, Missouri]], to [[Ethnic German|German]]-American parents. After a spiritual experience at age 13, several years later, she began itinerant preaching, with her elder sister and brother-in law, in [[Idaho]]. Later, she was ordained by the [[Evangelical Church Alliance]].<ref name=obitNY>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1976/02/22/archives/kathryn-kuhlman-evangelist-and-faith-healer-dies-in-tulsa.html | title=Kathryn Kuhlman, Evangelist And Faith Healer, Dies in Tulsa | publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=February 22, 1976 | first= Gary| last= Settle| accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref>
Kuhlman met Burroughs Waltrip, a Texas evangelist who was eight years her senior. Shortly after his visit to Denver, Waltrip divorced his wife, left his family and moved to [[Mason City, Iowa]], where he began a revival center called Radio Chapel. Kuhlman and her friend and pianist Helen Gulliford came into town to help him raise funds for his ministry. It was shortly after their arrival that the romance between Burroughs and Kuhlman became publicly known.
Burroughs and Kuhlman decided to wed. While discussing the matter with some friends, Kuhlman had said that she could not "find the will of God in the matter." These and other friends encouraged her not to go through with the marriage, but Kuhlman justified it to herself and others by believing that Waltrip's wife had left him, not the other way around. On October 18, 1938, she secretly married "Mister," as she liked to call Waltrip, in Mason City. The wedding did not give her new peace about their union, however. The couple had no children. Regarding her marriage, in a 1952 interview with the Denver Post, Kuhlman said, "He charged—correctly—that I refused to live with him. And I haven't seen him in eight years."<ref>Buckingham, J. (1976) Daughter of destiny: Kathryn Kuhlman...Her story. Plainfield, New Jersey: Logos International, p. 82 {{ISBN|0-88270-784-1}}</ref> She was divorced by Burroughs Waltrip in 1948.
==Ministry== Kuhlman traveled extensively around the United States and in many other countries holding "healing crusades" between the 1940s and 1970s. She was one of the most well-known healing ministers in the world.<ref name="obitNY" /> Kuhlman had a weekly [[TV program]] in the 1960s and 1970s called ''I Believe In Miracles'' that was aired nationally. She also had a 30-minute nationwide radio ministry of teaching from the Bible and frequently would feature excerpts from her healing services (both music and message). Her foundation was established in 1954, and its [[Canada|Canadian]] branch in 1970. Late in her life she was supportive of the nascent [[Jesus movement]], and received endorsements by its key leaders, including David Wilkerson and Chuck Smith.
By 1970 she moved to Los Angeles, conducting healing services for thousands of people each day as an heir to [[Aimee Semple McPherson]].<ref name="Kuhlman1970">{{cite news|url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/newspapers1/na0021/6793856/47241589_clean.html|title=Aimee Macpherson has a Dazzling Successor|last=|first=|date=July 4, 1970|work=|accessdate=2007-11-12|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=yes|publisher=[[Pasadena Star-News]]}}</ref> She became well known for her "gift of healing" despite, as she often noted, having no theological training.<ref name="Kuhlman1970"/>{{Dead link|date=March 2018}} She was friends with Christian television pioneer Pat Robertson and made guest appearances at his Christian Broadcasting Network (CBN) and on the network's flagship program "The 700 Club."
In 1975, Kuhlman was sued by Paul Bartholomew, her personal administrator, who claimed that she kept $1 million in jewelry and $1 million in fine art hidden away and sued her for $430,500 for breach of contract.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost_historical/access/120169428.html?dids=120169428:120169428&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=JUL+18%2C+1975&author=&pub=The+Washington+Post&desc=Evangelist+Sued+By+a+Former+Aide&pqatl=google | title=Evangelist Sued By a Former Aide | publisher=[[Washington Post]] |date=July 18, 1975 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/662183362.html?dids=662183362:662183362&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&date=Jul+03%2C+1975&author=RUSSELL+CHANDLER&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Ex-Aides+Sue+Kathryn+Kuhlman&pqatl=google |title=Ex-Aides Sue Kathryn Kuhlman | publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=July 3, 1975 | first= Russell| last= Chandler| accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref> Two former associates accused her in the lawsuit of diverting funds and of illegally removing records, which she denied and said the records were not private.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wOgNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=onkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5546,2534488&dq=kathryn+kuhlman | title=Kathryn Kuhlman Sued By Former Associates | publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=July 12, 1975 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> According to Kuhlman, the lawsuit was settled prior to trial.<ref name="Pittsburgh1975"/>
==Healing== Many accounts of medically documented healings were published in her books, which were [[ghostwriter|ghost-written]] by author Jamie Buckingham of Florida, including her autobiography, which was dictated at a hotel in [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]].<ref>Buckingham, J. (1976) Daughter of destiny: Kathryn Kuhlman...Her story. Plainfield, New Jersey: Logos International, p 167 {{ISBN|0-88270-784-1}}</ref> Buckingham also wrote his own Kuhlman biography that presented an unvarnished account of her life.<ref>Buckingham, J. (1976) Daughter of destiny: Kathryn Kuhlman...Her story. Plainfield, New Jersey: Logos International {{ISBN|0-88270-784-1}}</ref> An estimated two million people reported they were healed in her meetings over the years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/news/religion/famed-preacher-kathryn-kuhlman-died-here-years-ago/article_a09b9f6a-7b37-5184-91cb-9e85c36e5deb.html|title=Famed preacher Kathryn Kuhlman died here 40 years ago|last=SHERMAN|first=BILL|date=Feb 20, 2016|work=Tulsa World|access-date=2018-03-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref><!-- who made this statistic? Tulsa World, February 20, 2016 -->
Following a 1967 fellowship in Philadelphia, Dr. [[William A. Nolen]] conducted a case study of 23 people who said they had been cured during one of her services.<ref name="NoHealing">{{cite news |url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/newspapers1/na0030/5967824/21003862_clean.html | title=Psychic Healing? Investigator declares no | publisher=[[The Greenville News]] |date=August 16, 1975 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}} Also see: William Nolen, ''Healing: a doctor in search of a miracle''. New York: Random House {{ISBN|0-394-49095-9}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/newspapers1/na0022/6795006/48320964_clean.html | title=Dr Nolen Looks at Faith Healing | publisher=[[The San Mateo Times]] |date=March 7, 1975 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1975/02/02/archives/men-of-medicine-and-a-medicine-man.html | title=Men of medicine and a medicine man | publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=February 2, 1975 | first=Michael | last=Michaelson | accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913003,00.html | title=Extra-Dispensary Perceptions | publisher=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=March 17, 1975 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref> Nolen's long term follow-ups concluded that there were no cures in those cases. One woman who was said to have been cured of spinal cancer threw away her brace and ran across the stage at Kuhlman's command; her spine collapsed the next day and she died four months later.<ref name="Pittsburgh1975">{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cOQNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iG0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5291,834959&dq=kathryn+kuhlman+william+nolen|title=Inside Religion: Kuhlman Tested By MD's Probe|last=Lester|first=Kinsolving|date=November 8, 1975|work=|accessdate=2007-11-12|publisher=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4vMNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TnkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5343,1149932&dq=kathryn+kuhlman | title=A follow-up study of 23 patients 'cured' in a Kathryn Kuhlman service | publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=November 2, 1974 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref name="Kuhlman">{{cite book| last = Randi | first = James | authorlink = James Randi | year = 1989 | title = [[The Faith Healers]] | publisher = Prometheus Books | id = 228| isbn = 0-87975-535-0 }}</ref>
Nolen's analysis of Kulhman came in for criticism from believers. Lawrence Althouse, a physician, said that Nolen had attended only one of Kuhlman's services and did not follow up with all of those who said they had been healed there.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Rediscovering the Gift of Healing. Nashville: Abingdon,|last = Althaus|first = Lawrence|publisher = |year = 1977|isbn = |location = |pages = 59}}</ref> Dr. Richard Casdorph produced a book of evidence in support of miraculous healings by Kuhlman.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Miracles: A Medical Doctor Says Yes to Miracles!|last = Casdorph|first = Richard|publisher = |year = 1976|isbn = |location = |pages = 169}}</ref> Hendrik van der Breggen, a Christian philosophy professor, argued in favor of the claims.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Miracle Reports, Moral Philosophy, and Contemporary Science.|last = Hendrik van der|first = Breggen|publisher = |year = 2004|isbn = |location = |pages = 382}}</ref> Author Craig Keener concluded, "No one claims that everyone was healed, but it is also difficult to dispute that significant recoveries occurred, apparently in conjunction with prayer. One may associate these with Kathryn Kuhlman's faith or that of the supplicants, or, as in some of Kuhlman's teaching, to no one's faith at all; but the evidence suggests that some people were healed, even in extraordinary ways."<ref>{{Cite book|title = Miracles: The Credibility of the New Testament Accounts|last = Keener|first = Craig|publisher = |year = 2011|isbn = |location = |pages = 614 (ebook format)}}</ref>
Dr. Richard Owellen, a member of the cancer‐research department of the Johns Hopkins Hospital who appeared frequently at Miss Kuhlman's services, testified to various healings that he said he had investigated.<ref>Kathryn Kuhlman, Evangelist And Faith Healer, Dies in Tulsa, New York Times, Feb. 22, 1976.</ref>
==Death==
In 1955, in her late 40s, Kuhlman was diagnosed with a heart problem. She kept a very busy schedule, often traveling across the United States and around the world, holding two- to six-hour long meetings which ended late. In July 1975 her doctor diagnosed her with a minor heart flare-up; in November she had a relapse.<ref name="ObitPittsburgh">{{cite news | url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/newspapers1/na0034/6776963/33852475_clean.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130104021820/http://www.newspaperarchive.com/newspapers1/na0034/6776963/33852475_clean.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=January 4, 2013 | title=Kathryn Kuhlman Is Dead | publisher=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |date=February 21, 1976 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref> As a result, Kuhlman had open-heart surgery in [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] from which she died on February 20, 1976. <ref name="obitNY" /> Kathryn Kuhlman is interred in the [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Glendale, California]]. A plaque in her honor is in the main city park in Concordia, Missouri, a town in central Missouri on Interstate Highway 70.
After she died, her [[Will (law)|will]] led to controversy.<ref name="Bequests1976">{{cite news | url=http://www.newspaperarchive.com/newspapers1/na0023/6792967/46427475_clean.html | title=Kuhlman Bequests Listed | publisher=[[Independent Press-Telegram]] |date=April 17, 1976 | first= | last= | accessdate =2007-11-12}}</ref> She left $267,500, the bulk of her estate, to three family members and twenty employees. Smaller bequests were given to 19 other employees.<ref name="Bequests1976" />{{Dead link|date=March 2018}} According to the ''[[Independent Press-Telegram]]'', her employees were disappointed that "she did not leave most of her estate to the foundation as she had done under a previous 1974 will."<ref name="Bequests1976" /> The Kathryn Kuhlman Foundation had continued, but due to lack of funding, in 1982 terminated its nationwide radio broadcasting. Ultimately, the Foundation shut its doors in April 2016. <ref>https://www.charismanews.com/us/55287-kathryn-kuhlman-s-foundation-shutters-doors-40-years-after-her-death</ref>
==Legacy== For several decades there has been serious debate regarding the authenticity of Kuhlman's ministry. Some{{according to whom|date=September 2015}} would suggest that she was a modern-day [[prophet]] exercising the power of God. The debate continues today with many believers upholding Kuhlman as an important forerunner (including proponents of the "[[Prosperity Theology]]" and "[[Faith Healing]]" movement, such as [[Benny Hinn]]), and with some Christian [[Cessationism|cessationist]] apologists.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Counterfeit_Revival.html?id=mqxGNgAACAAJ|title=Counterfeit Revival|last=Hanegraaff|first=Hank|date=1997|publisher=Word Pub.|isbn=9780849938924|language=en}}</ref>Others argue the opposite: that is, that Kuhlman did not teach core tenents of "word of faith" and "hyper-prosperity" doctrine; for example she did not teach "little gods" doctrine, nor that Jesus suffered the pains of hell and thus needed to be born-again in hell. Significantly, neither did she teach that faith (on the part of the sick person) is always a prerequisite to supernatural healing, as is taught in classic "word of faith" doctrine.
Still, she influenced [[faith healers]] [[Benny Hinn]] and [[Billy Burke (evangelist)|Billy Burke]]. Hinn has adopted some of her techniques and wrote a book about her.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.csicop.org/si/2002-05/i-files.html |title=Benny Hinn: Healer or Hypnotist? |publisher=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |date=May–June 2002 |first=Joe |last=Nickell |accessdate=2007-11-12 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012200735/http://www.csicop.org/si/2002-05/i-files.html |archivedate=2007-10-12 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 1981 [[David Byrne]] and [[Brian Eno]] sampled one of Kuhlman's sermons in their album ''[[My Life in the Bush of Ghosts (album)|My Life in the Bush of Ghosts]]''. The track was entitled "The Spirit Womb," a mis-hearing of Kuhlman's actual utterance "the spirit world." When Kuhlman's estate refused to license the use of her voice, the track was re-recorded as "[[The Jezebel Spirit]]" with an unidentified exorcist's vocal replacing Kuhlman's.<ref name="Duke UP - 14 March 2011 - McLeod and DiCola - Creative License: The Law and Culture of Digital Sampling">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nOWdriHLHgQC&pg=PA169&dq=%22The+Jezebel+Spirit%22+Byrne#v=onepage&q=%22The%20Jezebel%20Spirit%22%20Byrne&f=false|title=Creative License: The Law and Culture of Digital Sampling|last=[[Kembrew McLeod]] and Peter DiCola|first=|date=14 March 2011|publisher=[[Duke University Press]]|year=|isbn=9780822348757|location=|pages=167|accessdate=11 February 2014}}</ref>
Questions about her were raised in the Crusaders Series of Christian Comics dealing with True Doctrine in the Church, which are published by [[Jack Chick]].
She appeared on ''The Tonight Show'' with Johnny Carson in 1974.<ref>{{Citation|title="The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson" Episode #13.196 (TV Episode 1974)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6473540/fullcredits|accessdate=2018-03-16}}</ref> Also, she was mentioned on more than one occasion on the ''[[Mary Tyler Moore ]]'' Show, as well as ''The Carol Burnett Show''.
[[Ruth Buzzi]] did a character based on Kuhlman on ''[[Rowan and Martin's Laugh In]]''.

{{For|the Anglican missionary bishop of the Falkland Islands|Lawrence Blair (bishop)}} {{other people|Larry Blair}} '''Lawrence Blair''', Ph.D. is an [[anthropologist]], [[author]], [[explorer]] and [[filmmaker]]. Born in [[England]], he has been a resident of [[Bali, Indonesia]] for the past 35 years.
==Life and career==
Lawrence Blair is the writer, presenter and co-producer of the internationally acclaimed TV series ''Ring of Fire'', an Emmy award nominee and winner of the 1989 National Educational Film and Video Festival Silver Apple awards.
Lawrence Blair emigrated from England to [[Mexico]] with his parents and his brother Lorne in his early years. He has been a diver in Mexico and [[Indonesia]], a fisherman in Alaska, an actor, a model, a [[photographer]] and an [[interpreter]]. He earned his Ph.D. at [[Lancaster University]], England with a doctoral thesis exploring and defining the field of Psycho-anthropology.<ref>[http://www.celebrityspeakers.com.au/environmental-speakers/lawrence-blair Profile for Lawrence Blair]</ref>
He wrote the book ''Rhythms of Vision: The Changing Patterns of Belief'' in 1976 in which he discussed [[sacred geometry]], [[subtle energy]], [[chakras]], spiritual [[planes of existence]] and many other topics, the book has been compared to the work of the [[occultist]] [[Corinne Heline]] and the [[theosophist]] [[Alice Bailey]]. The book is most well known for first discussing the [[Hundredth monkey effect]]. [[Lyall Watson]] was a friend of Blair's and wrote a foreword for the book.<ref>Lawrence Blair, [https://www.amazon.com/Rhythms-Vision-Changing-Patterns-Belief/dp/0805236104 Rhythms of Vision: The Changing Patterns of Belief]. London: [[Croom Helm Ltd.]], {{ISBN|978-0-8052-3610-1}}.</ref>
Blair starred in the [[documentary]] [[Ring of Fire (1991 film)]] which discussed the varieties of [[volcanism]] and [[earthquake]] activity around the [[Pacific Rim]].
He wrote, co-produced and starred in the five film series documentary called [[Ring of Fire: An Indonesian Odyssey]] which highlights a 10-year exploration of Indonesian [[Islands]], an adventure of Lawrence and his brother Lorne.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2010/07/16/lawrence-blair-witness-change.html | title=LAWRENCE BLAIR: Witness to Change | publisher= [[The Jakarta Post]]| date=July 16, 2010 | accessdate=December 9, 2012 | author=Chickering, Melinda | location=[[Sanur, Bali]]}}</ref> The series was later developed into a book of the same name.<ref>[http://www.indonesianodyssey.co.uk Indonesian Odyssey]</ref>
Blair's latest production was ''Myth, Magic and Monsters'' a four-Part documentary series, in which Blair explores the globe for rare and mysterious creatures which include reptiles, ocean dwellers and domesticated animals.<ref>[http://www.balidiscovery.com/messages/message.asp?Id=3618 Myth, Magic and Monsters]</ref> According to Blair: “There are still undiscovered species and tribes of people out there.”
In 2009, Blair appeared in the documentary film ''[[Oh My God (2009 film)|Oh My God]]'' in which people around the world were asked the question - "What is God?", Blair answered that God is not a belief and that "Thought is the enemy of the awareness of the presence of god."<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lawrence-blair-phd/ioh-my-godi-god-a-word-fo_b_351211.html Article, November, 2009]</ref><ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1326954/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast]</ref>
