{{italic title}} [[File:Hridaya jail.jpg|thumb|Chittadhar Hridaya, sketched in jail, ca. 1944.]] [[File:Suddhodana maskey.jpg|thumb|Illustration from ''Sugata Saurabha'' showing the Buddha's father [[Śuddhodana]].]] '''''Sugata Saurabha''''' ([[Devanagari]]: सुगत सौरभ) is an epic poem in [[Nepal Bhasa]] by [[Chittadhar Hridaya]] (1906 – 1982), one of the greatest literary figures from Nepal in the 20th century. ''Sugata Saurabha'', meaning “The Fragrant Life of the Buddha”, is based on the life story of [[Gautama Buddha]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/oso/public/content/religion/9780195341829/toc.html |title=Sugata Saurabha: An Epic Poem from Nepal on the Life of the Buddha by Chittadhar Hridaya |publisher=Oxford Scholarship Online |accessdate=24 February 2013 |date= }}</ref>
==Written in jail==
''Sugata Saurabha'' is Hridaya's greatest work which he composed while in prison from 1941 to 1945 in [[Kathmandu]]. He was given a six-year jail sentence for writing a poem in his mother tongue, which the autocratic [[Rana dynasty|Rana]] regime sought to suppress.<ref>Lewis, Todd T., and Tuladhar, Subarna Man (2009). ''Sugata Saurabha - An Epic Poem from Nepal on the Life of the Buddha by Chittadhar Hridaya.'' New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-534182-9}}. Page 6.</ref>
Hridaya wrote ''Sugata Saurabha'' in secret in prison, and his sister [[Moti Laxmi Upasika]] would smuggle out the scraps of paper on which he had scribbled the verses when she brought him his food.
==The storyline==
''Sugata Saurabha'' relates the Buddha's life from birth to enlightenment to death in 19 chapters. The life story is based on classical sources, but Hridaya has filled in details from the Nepalese sociocultural context where they are not mentioned.
The epic has been described as providing an aesthetically pleasing and doctrinally sound comprehensive account of the Buddha's life,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oxfordscholarship.com/oso/public/content/religion/9780195341829/toc.html |title=Sugata Saurabha: An Epic Poem from Nepal on the Life of the Buddha by Chittadhar Hridaya |publisher=Oxford Scholarship Online |accessdate=24 February 2013 |date= }}</ref> and a magnum opus in [[Nepal Bhasa literature]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Singh|first=Mahendra Man |title=Reading the ‘Kavi Kesari’ |url=http://www.ekantipur.com/the-kathmandu-post/2011/01/07/books/reading-the-kavi-kesari/216976/ |accessdate=24 February 2013 |newspaper=The Kathmandu Post|date=8 January 2011}}</ref>
The 19 chapters in ''Sugata Saurabha'' are entitled: 1. Lumbinī 2. Family Tree 3. Nativity 4. Mother 5. A Pleasant Childhood 6. Education 7. Marriage 8. The Great Renunciation 9. Yashodharā 10. Attaining Enlightenment 11. The Basic Teachings 12. The Blessed One in Kapilavastu 13. Handsome Nanda 14. The Great Lay Disciple 15. Twelve Years of Itinerant Preaching 16. A Dispute over Water 17. The Monastery Built by Vishākhā 18. Devadatta's Sacrilege and 19. Entry into Nirvāna.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=Sugata Saurabha: An Epic Poem from Nepal on the Life of the Buddha by Chittadhar Hridaya |publisher=Oxford Scholarship Online |date= |doi=10.1093/acprof:oso/9780195341829.001.0001/acprof-9780195341829 |doi-broken-date=2018-09-06 }}</ref>
==First publication==
Hridaya finished the epic in 1946, a year after he was released from prison. ''Sugata Saurabha'' was first published from [[Kolkata]], India in 1949. Artist [[Chandra Man Singh Maskey]], who was in jail with Hridaya for alleged political activities, did the color illustrations in ''Sugata Saurabha''.<ref>Lewis, Todd T., and Tuladhar, Subarna Man (2009). ''Sugata Saurabha - An Epic Poem from Nepal on the Life of the Buddha by Chittadhar Hridaya.'' New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-534182-9}}. Page 8.</ref>
==English translations==
Two English versions of ''Sugata Saurabha'' have been published. In 1998, an English translation by Tirtha Raj Tuladhar was published by the Nepal Bhasa Academy, Kathmandu.
In 2010, [[Oxford University Press]] published an English translation by Todd T. Lewis and Subarna Man Tuladhar.<ref>Lewis, Todd T., and Tuladhar, Subarna Man (2009). ''Sugata Saurabha - An Epic Poem from Nepal on the Life of the Buddha by Chittadhar Hridaya.'' New York: Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-534182-9}}.</ref> Lewis and Tuladhar won the 2011 Toshihide Numata Book Prize awarded by the Center for Buddhist Studies at the [[University of California]], Berkeley for their translation of the epic.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Sugata Saurabha wins book prize |url=http://www.ekantipur.com/the-kathmandu-post/2011/10/25/et-cetera/sugata-saurabha-wins-book-prize/227587.html |accessdate=24 February 2013 |newspaper=The Kathmandu Post|date=31 October 2011}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: Timeline of women in library science

revision.text:
This is a '''timeline of women in library science''' throughout the world.
1911: [[Theresa Elmendorf]] became the first woman elected president of the [[American Library Association]].<ref name=thomison>Thomison, p. 280 ''The death of her husband had forced Theresa Elmendorf to end her unpaid status, and for the next 20 years she held the position of vice-librarian at the Buffalo Public Library. Her new role also meant an increased participation in the American Library Association; in 1911–12 she served as its President, the first woman to hold that position.''</ref>
1912: Lillian Helena Smith became the first trained children's librarian in Canada in 1912.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://famouscanadianwomen.com/famous%20firsts/Academics%20and%20Librarians.htm |title=Famous Canadian Women's Famous Firsts - Academics and Librarians |publisher=Famouscanadianwomen.com |date= |accessdate=2016-08-10}}</ref>
1923: [[Virginia Proctor Powell Florence]] became the first black woman in the United States to earn a degree in library science.<ref name=Black>175 Years of Black Pitt People and Notable Milestones. (2004). Blue Black and Gold 2004: Chancellor Mark A. Norenberg Reports on the Pitt African American Experience, 44. Retrieved on 2009-05-22.</ref> She earned the degree (Bachelor of Library Science) from what is now part of the University of Pittsburgh.<ref name="nwhm">{{cite web |url=http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/africanamerican/25.html |title=Claiming Their Citizenship: African American Women From 1624–2009 |publisher=Nwhm.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120227155748/http://www.nwhm.org/online-exhibits/africanamerican/25.html |archivedate=2012-02-27 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Celeste Kimbrough |url=http://www.news.pitt.edu/news/university-pittsburgh-honor-first-african-american-librarian-plaque-dedication-ceremony-april-2 |title=University of Pittsburgh to Honor First African American Librarian In Plaque Dedication Ceremony April 2 | University of Pittsburgh News |publisher=News.pitt.edu |date=2004-03-18 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oberlin.edu/library/friends/perspectives/32.pdf |title=05-3180-Oberlin-Issue No.32 |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-10}}</ref>
1947: [[Freda Farrell Waldon]] became the first president of the [[Canadian Library Association]], and thus, as she was female, its first female president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hpl.ca/waldon-freda-farrell |title=Waldon, Freda Farrell | HPL |publisher=Hpl.ca |date= |accessdate=2016-08-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cla.ca/cla-at-work/ |title=CLA AT WORK |publisher=cla.ca |date= |accessdate=2016-08-10}}</ref>
1972: [[Zoia Horn]], born in Ukraine, became the first United States librarian to be jailed for refusing to share information as a matter of conscience (and, as she was female, the first female United States librarian to do so.)<ref>{{cite web|last=Egelko |first=Bob |url=http://www.sfgate.com/nation/article/Zoia-Horn-1st-U-S-librarian-jailed-over-alleged-5624023.php |title=Zoia Horn, librarian jailed for not testifying against protesters |publisher=SFGate |date=2014-07-15 |accessdate=2016-08-04}}</ref>
1973: Page Ackerman became University Librarian for the [[University of California, Los Angeles]], and was the United States's first female librarian of a system as large and complex as UCLA's.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/Obituary-Page-Ackerman-Former-6884 |title=Obituary: Page Ackerman, Former UCLA University Librarian |accessdate=2006-12-13 |author=Setzer, Dawn |date=2006-03-09 |work=UCLA News }}</ref>
1993: Jennifer Tanfield became the first female Librarian of the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Department of the Official Report (Hansard), House of Commons, Westminster |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm199899/cmhansrd/vo990721/debtext/90721-21.htm |title=House of Commons Hansard Debates for 21 Jul 1999 (pt 21) |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-08-12}}</ref>
1999: Elisabeth Niggermann became the first female director general of the [[German National Library]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dnb.de/EN/Wir/Geschichte/geschichte_node.html|title=History|publisher=Deutsche National Bibliothek|accessdate=14 August 2016 |language=}}</ref>
2000: [[Lynne Brindley]] was appointed as the first female chief executive of the [[British Library]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/feb/09/3|title=Woman to head British Library|publisher=''The Guardian''|date=9 February 2000|accessdate=14 August 2016 |language=}}</ref>
2002: Inez Lynn was appointed as the first female librarian in the [[London Library]]'s history.<ref>{{cite web|author=yesterday |url=http://www.londonlibrary.co.uk/about-us/historyofthelondonlibrary |title=History of The London Library |publisher=Londonlibrary.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-08-10}}</ref>
2012: [[Sonia L'Heureux]] became the first female [[Parliamentary Librarian of Canada]].<ref name=hilltimes>"Meet Canada’s first female Parliamentary librarian: Sonia L’Heureux". ''[[The Hill Times]]'', July 9, 2012.</ref>
2016: Laurence Engel became the first female head of the [[French National Library]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/culture/2016/04/06/03004-20160406ARTFIG00175-laurence-engel-nommee-a-la-tete-de-la-bnf.php|title=Laurence Engel nommée à la tête de la BnF|publisher=''Le Figaro''|date=6 April 2016|accessdate= 14 August 2016|language=French}}</ref>
2016: [[Carla Hayden]] became the first female [[Librarian of Congress]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/9/14/12916522/carla-hayden-librarian-of-congress |title=Carla Hayden is officially sworn in as the first woman and African-American librarian of Congress |publisher=Vox |date=2016|accessdate=2016-09-14}}</ref>

Wood | honorific_suffix = | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1818 | death_date = 31 August 1882 {{Death year and age|1882|1818}} | birth_place = [[Wake County, North Carolina]] | death_place = off [[Point Lookout, Maryland]] | placeofburial = | placeofburial_label = | placeofburial_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | nickname = | birth_name = | allegiance = {{flag|United States of America|1845}} | branch = {{flag|United States Navy}} | serviceyears = 1845–1880 | rank = | servicenumber = | unit = | commands = [[Bureau of Steam Engineering]] | battles = [[American Civil War]] | battles_label = | awards = | relations = | laterwork = | signature = }} '''William W. W. Wood''' (1818–31 August 1882) was an engineer of the [[United States Navy]], who served as Engineer-in-Chief of the [[Bureau of Steam Engineering]] from 1873 until 1877.
==Biography== Wood was born in [[Wake County, North Carolina]], and after graduation obtained a position at the [[West Point Foundry]].<ref name="harpers">{{cite journal |last= |first= |author= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=November 26, 1864 |title=Chief-Engineer W. W. Wood |journal=[[Harper's Weekly]] |volume=VIII |issue=413 |page=764 |accessdate=23 March 2012 |url=http://www.sonofthesouth.net/leefoundation/civil-war/1864/november/president-lincoln-home-springfield.htm }}</ref>
He was appointed to the navy from New York on 15 March 1845 with the rank of chief engineer.<ref name=NYTObituary>{{cite news |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1882/09/02/102785121.pdf |title=Chief Engineer Wood drowned |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2 September 1882 |issn=0362-4331 |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref><ref name=Promotions>{{cite web |url= http://www.history.navy.mil/books/callahan/reg-usn-w.htm |title=Officers of the Continental and US Navy and Marine Corps 1775–1900 (W) |work=[[Naval Historical Center]] |year=2006 |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> He spent his first two years in the navy stationed at the [[Naval Air Station Pensacola#Navy yard|Pensacola Navy Yard]], Florida.<ref name=NYTObituary/> He briefly did special duty at Boston, and then from 1850 to 1853 served on the paddle-sloop {{USS|Saranac|1848|2}} in the [[Home Squadron]].<ref name=NYTObituary/>
From 1854 to 1857, Wood superintended the constructions of the engines of the screw-frigate {{USS|Merrimack|1855|2}} at Cold Spring, New York.<ref name=NYTObituary/> His next appointment was for two years serving in the screw-sloop {{USS|Lancaster|1858|2}} on the [[Pacific Squadron]].<ref name=NYTObituary/> From 1862 to 1866 Wood spent most of his time on special duty in Philadelphia, New York and Boston.<ref name=NYTObituary/> Wood was assigned to the [[United States Naval Academy]] from 1866 to 1867.<ref name=NYTObituary/> Wood was Inspector of Machinery Afloat in New York from 1870 to 1872.<ref name=NYTObituary/>
Wood was promoted to engineer-in-chief in 1872,<ref name=NYTObituary/> and was appointed Chief of the [[Bureau of Steam Engineering]] on 20 March 1873,<ref name=Promotions/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.history.navy.mil/library/guides/rosters/steam.htm |title=Bureau of Steam Engineering - Lists of Commanding Officers and Senior Officials of the US Navy |work=Navy Department Library |year=2006 |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref> his successor was appointed on 3 March 1877.<ref name=Promotions/> Wood was assigned to special duty in 1878,<ref name=NYTObituary/> and was placed on the retired list on 31 May 1880.<ref name=Promotions/>
==Death== On 31 August 1882 Wood was drowned in a boating accident off [[Point Lookout, Maryland]].<ref name=NYTObituary/>
==Family== At the time of his death, Wood was married and had six children: * Fanny Henderson, wife of Lt. Conway Hillyer Arnold, USN * Mary Eliza, wife of Lt. Eugene DeForest Heald, USN * Leiley Weir, wife of Lt. Charles Allston Stone, USN * Lt. Thomas Newton Wood, USN * Emily Grace, wife of Lt. Henry Frick Reich, USN * Master Francis Gregory Wood
Two more, William Willis Wood and Charles Gillespie Wood, had died young.
